excerpts: I highly recommend the Mexican Grilled Chicken Salad (sans red onions).
mexican grilled chicken salad.author: Lauren W.
mexican grilled chicken salad.review: I like this place!  It's handy (less than a block from my office), the food is consistently good, service is fast and the patio on a sunny day is a pretty awesome change from sitting inside my freezing office.   I've been here many times but most recently last Thursday with a girlfriend from work.  I decided to try the white wine and it wasn't horrible.  I knew I was ordering chardonnay from a mexican place near the ballpark so I wasn't expecting much, but it was drinkable so that is a win to me!  I highly recommend the Mexican Grilled Chicken Salad (sans red onions).

excerpts: My favorite dishes are the mexican grilled chicken salad, tortilla soup and the grilled chicken burrito.
mexican grilled chicken salad.author: Heron C.
mexican grilled chicken salad.review: I'm a big fan of this place. Sure it isn't the most authentic mexican food you can get in San Francisco. But, it is fresh, healthy and flavorful. The portions are big and the prices are very reasonable. I was so happy when this place moved in because SOMA really needs more locally owned mom and pop type restaurants, which this place is. The staff and owners are always nice and its just an overall nice place to eat. Lots of room, nice decor and the back patio is great on sunny days. My favorite dishes are the mexican grilled chicken salad, tortilla soup and the grilled chicken burrito.

excerpts: Chicken tortilla soup.
All pretty flavorless.
tortilla soup.author: Kim G.
tortilla soup.review:
When I looked through the window and the place was empty, I was hopeful it was just a fluke. I was sadly mistaken. The atmosphere was cool, the staff was nice enough... Things not to order... Steak Fajitas, Steak burrito (too dry) Wet steak burrito... Chicken tortilla soup. All pretty flavorless. Chips and salsa also don't come with the meal, you can buy it separately for $5 and they look like they came right off the grocery store shelf...
Just pop off the lid. There was silverware, but drinks come in a solo cup or tin can. Sorry...

excerpts: Why does it take 10 minutes for them to deliver a bowl of tortilla soup when there's hardly anyone in there?
tortilla soup.author: Kevin B.
tortilla soup.review:
Slow, slow, slow.  Consistently slow.

Why does it take 10 minutes for them to deliver a bowl of tortilla soup when there's hardly anyone in there?

You take your ladel, plop some soup into a bowl, and throw in some tortilla strips.

Seriously.

excerpts: I wish I had thought to take a photo of my bf's "tortilla soup" for failblog...
I observed this process and presentation--- are you ready?
Ok:
Literally, they scooped some chicken and...
liquid (?)
from what I am almost CERTAIN is the container of mild chicken used for burritos and put it in a bowl.
Then, in they placed some avocado chunks, some cojita cheese, and some cold roasted corn into 3 individual plastic cups, and teetered them on the edge of the bowl.
Voila!
Tortilla soup!
That will be $6.50, please.
tortilla soup.author: Laura F.
tortilla soup.review:
Free associating words with my experience here:  Stressful... overpriced... bland... messy... sh*t show!

Also, I don't know who said to themselves, "You know what this area needs?  ANOTHER Mexican joint!  I mean, there's only like, 4 others in a 5-block radius!  We don't need culinary prowess, we've got ATMOSPHERE!  Surely this is what will make people seeking burritos choose us!"

I wish I had thought to take a photo of my bf's "tortilla soup" for failblog... I observed this process and presentation--- are you ready?  Ok:  Literally, they scooped some chicken and... liquid (?) from what I am almost CERTAIN is the container of mild chicken used for burritos and put it in a bowl.  Then, in they placed some avocado chunks, some cojita cheese, and some cold roasted corn into 3 individual plastic cups, and teetered them on the edge of the bowl.  Voila!  Tortilla soup!  That will be $6.50, please.  
*Notice that nowhere did I make mention of anything resembling, oh, i don't know... a tortilla?

That was probably the most amusing offense, but rest assured: nothing tasted like anything, the open area where food is assembled/plated was a disaster (wiping knives on filthy aprons, etc), they place their soft tacos on to paper sheets that stick to the tortilla (thus making it impossible to pick up the taco lest you rip the bottom off), and the salsa is... I don't even know what the hell is in it, let alone what it's supposed to taste like.

Run awaaaaaaaaaay!

excerpts: Tortilla Soup - absolutely delicious.
Ate for dinner, and lunch the next day.
The chicken in the soup i had for lunch was WAY too big, and slightly dry.
But everything else was yummy.

2) Atmosphere - great space, great location, outdoor seating
3)
tortilla soup.author: Lacey H.
tortilla soup.review:
Wow, I'm surprised the overall star rating for this place is so low!  I'm a big fan of this place.  It is true, that there are things that could be changed for the better, but i think that's the case with all new restaurants.  I came here the week after they opened.  Met some girlfriends here for dinner and drinks, and came again for lunch the following day with my company for my boss's birthday.  Instead of doing pros and cons, although the cons should definitely be taken as "constructive" criticism since they can easily be changed.

Pros:
1) Tortilla Soup - absolutely delicious.  Ate for dinner, and lunch the next day.  The chicken in the soup i had for lunch was WAY too big, and slightly dry.  But everything else was yummy.
2) Atmosphere - great space, great location, outdoor seating
3) Salsa - Yummers
4) The owners are very polite and accommodating.  They brought our food to us, brought flatware and napkins (even though we realized later we were supposed to get it ourselves)
5) Good red and white wine selections
6) Great prices - great happy hour speicals

Constructive Criticism:
1) Staff behind the counter needs to be a little more polite.  They must be new to food service, because they don't seem to understand the phrase, "the customer is always right"
2) Staff behind the cash register needs to be a little more assertive and move the line along.  I waited at the counter while the cashier pushed chips around and got salsa... the line was piling up behind me, so i said, "can i pay?" and he said, "oh, yay..."
3) No margaritas - Was a little disappointed they weren't serving margaritas, but the red wine selection was pretty good.  
4) Tacos are a little dry - perhaps they should add a "wetter" salsa (salsa verde?) to their selection - and not over steam their rice...
5) Tacos should not automatically come with sour cream

excerpts: I got the tortilla soup, which was just tomato soup with some veggies and chicken thrown in.
Bland.
tortilla soup.author: miss k.
tortilla soup.review: Food was eh, and bland. I'll stick to me El Farolito thank you very much. I got the tortilla soup, which was just tomato soup with some veggies and chicken thrown in. Bland. And a baby burrito, which was fairly big and that was bland too. And the guy taking our order didn't look like he wanted to be somewhere else.

excerpts: Wife ordered the tortilla soup.
tortilla soup.author: Green Devil W.
tortilla soup.review:
Wasn't it Chevy's who coined the phrase no "smashed beans and rice?"
Well the Mission Bay now has an amazing option for "Gringo-ized" Mexican fare. But really this food could fit in with the best of the Mission district. 

The interior is bare wood and the menu is written on a chalkboard. The menu expands beyond just burritos and tacos and hopes to appease all types of people (read: you can even get tofu). They have many beers on tap and even serve wine!

Had to go with the basics and tried the carnitas burrito. I was advised that it is sold as a wet burrito with my choice of three sauces. I opted for the green. Wife ordered the tortilla soup. 

The hearty and healthy soup arrived to the table first (rather lukewarm) with a side plate of additional garnish including: corn, tortilla strips, queso fresco and fresh tomatoes. It could of used more of a kick but that is just personal preference and the table had two delicious salsas to add. The burrito had the largest chunks of pork I've ever seen in a taqueria. The green sauce that bathed the entire burrito was soooo yummy.

I used to hit Subway at the Caltrain station prior to heading down the peninsula but now I have a new vice!!!

excerpts: My tortilla soup came out luke warm and PILED with chicken and accompanied by three plastic cups of toppings (wtf?):   cojita, tomatoes and corn.
Normally I wouldn't complain about the overabundance of meat, but the soup was a failure.
The broth was one-note, not at all spicy, and the whole thing entirely devoid of actual tortilla strips.
I'd give it a 2/10 on a good day.
My mistakenly gratis taco was just as unimpressive, though the pork itself wasn't terrible.
The worst part about this dish by far was the fact that the moist corn tortilla almost entirely stuck to the paper beneath it.
See ya later, hand to mouth taco eating.
I'll take my business back to Au Parc, or better yet, wait until after work to hit up La Taq or Papalote to get my fix.
tortilla soup.author: Dean F.
tortilla soup.review:
This place is certainly not suffering from a "they're new, they have a lot of kinks to figure out" problem.  They're suffering from a "the food is really pretty terrible, and horrendously overpriced" problem.  
Figured the gf and I would give the new workplace neighbor a try for lunch.  The ordering process was a bit chaotic and left a lot of room for errors...errors including who I assume is the co-owner not ringing me up for my carnitas taco.  
The ambiance is actually pretty cool and fits with the whole warehouse SoMa vibe, but clearly the proprietors spent much more time on the decor than the menu.
Back to the food.  My tortilla soup came out luke warm and PILED with chicken and accompanied by three plastic cups of toppings (wtf?):   cojita, tomatoes and corn.  Normally I wouldn't complain about the overabundance of meat, but the soup was a failure.  The broth was one-note, not at all spicy, and the whole thing entirely devoid of actual tortilla strips.  I'd give it a 2/10 on a good day.
My mistakenly gratis taco was just as unimpressive, though the pork itself wasn't terrible.  The worst part about this dish by far was the fact that the moist corn tortilla almost entirely stuck to the paper beneath it.  See ya later, hand to mouth taco eating.  
I'll take my business back to Au Parc, or better yet, wait until after work to hit up La Taq or Papalote to get my fix.

excerpts: The chicken tortilla soup is to die for as is the ceviche.
The moles used for burritos give them a great spin from the norm.
tortilla soup.author: P H.
tortilla soup.review:
I live across the street from TIC.  It opened right along with our moving in.  They also own the Creamery coffee shop attached - i thought this was a great model.  I wanted to take a moment to give a huge high five review for this restaurant.  Amidst the vast array of greasy spoon styled Mexican food spots (which don't get me wrong, I love as well), The Iron Cactus stands out as a healthy, thoughtful and noteworthily flavored option.  The basic foods chosen are all organic.  All chicken meat is white and of the highest grade.  The chicken tortilla soup is to die for as is the ceviche.  The moles used for burritos give them a great spin from the norm.  I highly recommend a stop in if you haven't tried.

Beyond that, the service is exceptional - everyone is so polite, service oriented, and just all around nice.  I walked by during an electrical outage that had the entire 2 block radius out of service and they kept doors open with candles and everyone sitting eating together.  

Please take a moment to support this new locally owned restaurant.  Hopefully you'll add as a favorite.

excerpts: Super burrito is my go to
if I'm too hungry to last the train ride some.
Staff is always friendly.
burrito.author: Alex G.
burrito.review:
Super burrito is my go to if I'm too hungry to last the train ride some. Staff is always friendly. Sometimes I get free chops, sometimes I have to pay ‍

Place is clean, and has several tvs playing various games.

excerpts: This ain't no Mission burrito.
burrito.
burrito.author: Gabriela W.
burrito.review:
If you care about your health, fear ecoli, and hepatitis B, don't risk your health by dining at Iron Cactus.

I'll start off with the obvious. This isn't a legit taqueria. This ain't no Mission burrito. This is a sorry excuse for Mexican, and a serious threat to your health.

I'm about to break it down:

Red salsa is greasy, green salsa needs avocado and more spice. Slow down, I'm 100% Mexican, which gives me license to drop these truth bombs. I'll continue. Employees have an attitude. They look annoyed, as if you're doing them a favor by eating there. There's a blonde gentleman that usually takes the orders, and he's guaranteed to mix things up. Have them repeat your order. Twice. If he's not there, that place isn't run professionally. Case and point, my visit with my toddler, on 5/31/18. We drop in about 1:30p. I order for both my daughter and myself. The gentleman that brings our food has a glove on only one hand, which I immediately find strange,  as he's carrying another dish in his un-gloved hand. He drops our entrees off, then proceeds to bus all of the dirty tables, followed by him entering the food preparation area and picking up more entrees for guests. Still with the same dirty glove on. He drops them off at their respective tables. With the same dirty-ass glove on. I mention this to the lady at the cash register, who appears to also be filling the manager role. I tell her it's not a safe practice and he needs to remove his one glove and wash his hands after bussing dirty tables, before picking up guests' food. She agrees to talk to him. She does, then he removes his dirty glove and happily prepares his own lunch at the food preparation area-without washing his hands prior to doing so. If I needed a sign that none of my message had landed with the manager, it came quickly. She takes a new client's order, rings him up, heads straight to the food preparation area without washing her hands, grabs a tortilla and throws it on the grill, patting the tortilla several times, heads to the dining area to bus tables (as ALL of the employees are taking their lunch (this never happens when the gentleman I mention above is acting as the manager), buses tables, heads jack to the food preparation area without washing her hands after handling two tables-worth of dirty dishes, and continues to grab the tortilla off the grill with her bare hands and hands the dude his hepatitis A burrito. WT-----! Seriously, no concept of cleanliness, sanitation, germ and disease transmission! 

They wear a glove in one hand to give the impression that they understand cleanliness and disease transmission prevention. The above clearly paints a very different picture. I. Rest. My. Case. And for the record, I'm a nurse. I know a little something about disease transmission/prevention.

Pros
-Very friendly staff
-Salsas had good flavor and heat 
-$3 beer during happy hour

Cons
-Burrito was bland. 

I'm new to the area and decided to stop in. The place was very clean and I got my void very quick. I ordered an al pastor super burrito. There was too much sour cream- it dominated the burrito and could barely taste the other ingredients. It all kind of blended together. But the place was spacious, clean, and they had some good beers on draft. I won't go back if I am just looking for something to eat but would happily go back to drink and hang out.

burrito.review: I decided to stop by here before catching the Caltrain as it was close by and seemed lively. The service was good but I was a bit disappointed with the food. excerpts:
(People were complaining about "small sizes", I'm a 6'2" 200lb athlete, and I was full on a burrito.)

burrito.author: Sean M.
burrito.review:
*Rant coming*
Wow, I'm shocked by the other reviews.  Some complaining about the "quality", others about the "quantity", others about the "pricing"...talk about hypercritical yelpers.

Sure, you can get cheaper, but you'd sacrifice quality as well as atmosphere.  Sure you can get better, but you'll certainly pay for it.  Sure, you can get more, but you'll probably sacrifice quality and pricing.  
*Rant ended*

Now, the rexiew...

The spot is in a perfect location first of all.  We jumped off Caltrain on our way to AT&T park, but instead of paying $20+ for junk food there, we saw this across the street from the train station and headed over.  First, I was pretty impressed by their menu.  A good variety of typical Mexican taqueria classics, plus an added bonus for me.  They actually have an alternative to meat which isn't very common in Mexican spots.  They had tofu burritos.  Love it.  

On top of the diverse menu, the atmosphere is pretty cool.  Certainly nicer than a typical hole in the wall taqueria, more restaurant vibe.  Lots of vintage(or vintage looking) wood, bid tables, consistent decor.  It all fits the vibe well.  It is an "order and sit" spot, which is nice and casual.  The people working there were super nice and friendly.

Now to the food...the food was good.  
Was it the best Mexican food ever?  No.  
Was it quality?  Yes.  
Were the portions substantial?  Yes.  
(People were complaining about "small sizes", I'm a 6'2" 200lb athlete, and I was full on a burrito.)
Was it worth the $? Yes. 
(We had two meals and a sangria for $20.)

I'd certainly come back next time I'm hitting a Giants game, probably try something different for fun next time.
