excerpts: I ordered a veggie burrito with mild salsa and a green melon juice.
The juice and the chips that came along with it were quite tasty; however, I found the burrito to be somewhat bland.
Perhaps it would be better with spicy salsa?
It was quite filling though.
I think I would only come back if it was my last option...
veggie burrito.author: Carol M.
veggie burrito.review: I decided to stop by here before catching the Caltrain as it was close by and seemed lively. The service was good but I was a bit disappointed with the food. I ordered a veggie burrito with mild salsa and a green melon juice. The juice and the chips that came along with it were quite tasty; however, I found the burrito to be somewhat bland. Perhaps it would be better with spicy salsa? It was quite filling though. I think I would only come back if it was my last option...

excerpts: When I asked they said they charged me for a veggie burrito, which is not what I ordered, and this is literally the tinniest
veggie burrito.author: Blake G.
veggie burrito.review: Came here trying to find a new lunch spot for work. Seriously? I know San Francisco prices, but $8 for a freaking bean rice burrito? What a joke. When I asked they said they charged me for a veggie burrito, which is not what I ordered, and this is literally the tinniest burrito I've ever seen. Not to mention the stale rice! Yeah, no thanks guys. I'll wait until after work to get my burrito fix if that's the way you guys wanna play ball.

excerpts: I got a veggie burrito bowl after verbally wrestling with the staff.
I attempted to explain my food allergies in both English and Spanish, neither of which worked.
Still not really sure if they were being honest or just agreeing to get me out of their face.
...guess I'll find out in a couple hours if the reaction hits.
The veggies on the burrito bowl were soggy and poorly cooked.
Really just a pile of bland zucchini.
Gave them two stars instead of one because the rice was pretty good.
The veggies on the burrito bowl were soggy and poorly cooked.
Really just a pile of bland zucchini.
Gave them two stars instead of one because the rice was pretty good.
veggie burrito.author: Natalie P.
veggie burrito.review:
Not impressed with food or service. I got a veggie burrito bowl after verbally wrestling with the staff. I attempted to explain my food allergies in both English and Spanish, neither of which worked. Still not really sure if they were being honest or just agreeing to get me out of their face. ...guess I'll find out in a couple hours if the reaction hits. 
The veggies on the burrito bowl were soggy and poorly cooked. Really just a pile of bland zucchini. 
Gave them two stars instead of one because the rice was pretty good.

excerpts: I order the same thing: baby veggie burrito with tofu and guacamole.
Every single time they charge me $1 extra for guacamole and they never put guacamole in it.
veggie burrito.author: Terry D.
veggie burrito.review:
I've been to Iron Cactus many times, when I lived in SOMA, when I visit the ballpark or just in the area.  I like tofu in my burrito and they are the only place I know of with a sauteed tofu option.

The food is less than decent. Edible.  I wouldn't say it's nasty or gross but it's not great or anything.

1 star because the service is just horrible.  Every time I go to Iron Cactus I order the same thing: baby veggie burrito with tofu and guacamole.  Every single time they charge me $1 extra for guacamole and they never put guacamole in it.  I seriously have to watch them like a hawk when they make my burrito and scream over the glass wall to make sure they put guac in.  I'm tired of paying extra and not getting what I ordered. 

Once when I told them there was no quacamole in my burrito, not only did they not make me a new one, they just plopped some guac in a to-go cup.  What the heck am I suppose to do with that? DIp my burrito in guac?

This past visit last week will be our last Iron Cactus visit.  My husband ordered a Chimichanga.  We waited for about 15 minutes and no food.  Everyone else who ordered after us (and spoke Spanish to the workers) got their food.  Then a lady comes up to us, after we waited over 15 minutes and tells us they cannot make a Chimichanga and that we need to order something else.  WTF? If you know you cannot make a chimichanga when we order, then say so.  Don't tell us to change our order after we've already waited for so long.  Oh and of course during that whole time we were waiting? No one was making my tofu burrito.  So total wait time? almost 1/2 an hour! They didn't even reduce the price of my husband's replacement burrito.  He was charged the chimichanga price.

WTH. This place is no bueno!

excerpts: The chips were cold and stale and my super veggie burrito was less than delicious.
It was bland and the veggie mixture just wasn't good.
Who puts giant coin-cut carrots in a burrito?
That just ruins the texture.
veggie burrito.author: Rowena L.
veggie burrito.review: I'd actually walked into The Creamery next door but they had already closed their kitchen so I went into the Iron Cactus. The chips were cold and stale and my super veggie burrito was less than delicious. It was bland and the veggie mixture just wasn't good. Who puts giant coin-cut carrots in a burrito? That just ruins the texture.

excerpts:
I got the super veggie burrito with tofu which was just ok.  
I asked for a bowl but was given a burrito instead.
I paid for the super variety but hardly got any guac and sour cream in my burrito.
veggie burrito.author: Nina V.
veggie burrito.review:
Hmm...I don't think this place is atrocious like some Yelpers, but I don't think I'll be back if I'm craving Mexican food.  I got the super veggie burrito with tofu which was just ok.  A couple of downsides:

1.  I asked for a bowl but was given a burrito instead.
2.  I asked for spicy salsa inside, which was mild at best.
3.  The red salsa at the "salsa bar" had a weird honey taste which I didn't care for.
4.  I paid for the super variety but hardly got any guac and sour cream in my burrito.

The upsides:
1.  Good green salsa - yummy in fact.
2.  Chips were fresher than Taco Bell's.

In this case, there were too many downsides and hence the (2.5) star review. Like I said, I probably won't be back.

excerpts: so far- first time had the taco salad with tofu, second time had a veggie burrito with tofu.
I'm fairly certain the burrito had more lettuce in it than my salad did.
I couldn't really taste the gauc in my burrito, or the sour cream, and come on now, the cheese should be included (not cost extra!).
The rice was, to be honest, pretty crap- mushy, and spicy- but not in a flavorful way.
The rice needs to be not total mush and it'd be nice to have a plain rice option, or at least a less seasoned one.
Also, there were soggy peas and carrots in my burrito-
these things have no place being in a burrito.

Actually, so much so that it sets my expectations really high- the great decor with dark wood and beautiful lanterns make me feel like I'm in a nice Mexican restaraunt, not a grab n' go burrito place.....
and so it follows that I expect certain things.
Namely, margaritas.
When this place opened, I read the menu 4 times just to make sure I wasn't missing something.
How can a Mexican place not have Margaritas???"
It looked like the kind of place that would have great ritas.

Yes, I know, Tres Agaves is right down the street, and yes, I understand this is a taqueria (even though it looks like a restaraunt), and that liquor licenses are expensive, but I still want a darn 'rita.
Pitchers of them would add so much to this place.
A 'rita  alone would add a star or two here.
I hear they have sangria, which helps, but it's still not a margarita.
veggie burrito.author: Kristen L.
veggie burrito.review:
This place has potential, but right now it's sittin' at 2.5 stars for me. With a few minor changes they'd easily be 3 stars in my book, maybe even up to 4 stars, but that would take more.... I'll get to that. 

I've been here twice so far- first time had the taco salad with tofu, second time had a veggie burrito with tofu. I'm fairly certain the burrito had more lettuce in it than my salad did. I couldn't really taste the gauc in my burrito, or the sour cream, and come on now, the cheese should be included (not cost extra!). The rice was, to be honest, pretty crap- mushy, and spicy- but not in a flavorful way. The rice needs to be not total mush and it'd be nice to have a plain rice option, or at least a less seasoned one. Also, there were soggy peas and carrots in my burrito- these things have no place being in a burrito. This is not Forrest Gump goes to the tacqueria, people- leave the mushy canned veggies out!

As for the tofu, I think they might be using silken tofu, or at least it tastes that way- the tofu needs to be grilled and firmer. I know, I know, it's TOFU, it's not supposed to taste great... but the thing is, when it's done well, it does. This tofu is mushy and tasteless. I think this would be a fairly easy fix- buy extra firm tofu, prep it correctly, grill it, don't leave it sitting in a vat of water/sauce with soggy canned vegetables.

The salad, too, would be an easy fix- add more lettuce, maybe mixed greens.... as it was, I felt like I was eating a bowl full of toppings. Blech. 

Ok, now the pros, and the potential-
I LOVE the atmosphere here. Actually, so much so that it sets my expectations really high- the great decor with dark wood and beautiful lanterns make me feel like I'm in a nice Mexican restaraunt, not a grab n' go burrito place.....and so it follows that I expect certain things. Namely, margaritas. When this place opened, I read the menu 4 times just to make sure I wasn't missing something. "How can a Mexican place not have Margaritas???"  It looked like the kind of place that would have great ritas. Yes, I know, Tres Agaves is right down the street, and yes, I understand this is a taqueria (even though it looks like a restaraunt), and that liquor licenses are expensive, but I still want a darn 'rita. Pitchers of them would add so much to this place. A 'rita  alone would add a star or two here. I hear they have sangria, which helps, but it's still not a margarita. Also, good sangria has booze in addition to wine in it, so I'm skeptical....unless they just get a liquor license. 

More on pros: beer on draft, good beer selection, and very generous wine pours. The chips are pretty good. Outdoor patio and convenient location. Friendly staff. 

Like I said, potential. But right now my favorite part is the decor, not the food.

excerpts: Third Street Grill made this mistake when it first opened, too, but it has since added a veggie burrito option with lower pricing.

Also, service at The Iron Cactus is super slow and inefficient -- maybe they should take some tips from Mexico Au Parc (which I am also not too keen on but which I do not loathe) to see how to cycle people through?
veggie burrito.author: Midori S.
veggie burrito.review: I, too, loathe Victor's and Chavo's and was super excited to see The Iron Cactus open shop. The space is cool, and the burritos are actually better than the aforementioned places'. However, The Iron Cactus is super uncool to charge the same amount for burritos with without meat as for burritos with meat. That's $5.90 for a "baby burrito" (rice, beans, salsa; cheese is extra). Third Street Grill made this mistake when it first opened, too, but it has since added a veggie burrito option with lower pricing. Also, service at The Iron Cactus is super slow and inefficient -- maybe they should take some tips from Mexico Au Parc (which I am also not too keen on but which I do not loathe) to see how to cycle people through?

excerpts: The chips were cold and stale and my super veggie burrito was less than delicious.
It was bland and the veggie mixture just wasn't good.
Who puts giant coin-cut carrots in a burrito?
That just ruins the texture.
super veggie burrito.author: Rowena L.
super veggie burrito.review: I'd actually walked into The Creamery next door but they had already closed their kitchen so I went into the Iron Cactus. The chips were cold and stale and my super veggie burrito was less than delicious. It was bland and the veggie mixture just wasn't good. Who puts giant coin-cut carrots in a burrito? That just ruins the texture.

excerpts:
I got the super veggie burrito with tofu which was just ok.  
I asked for a bowl but was given a burrito instead.
I paid for the super variety but hardly got any guac and sour cream in my burrito.
super veggie burrito.author: Nina V.
super veggie burrito.review:
Hmm...I don't think this place is atrocious like some Yelpers, but I don't think I'll be back if I'm craving Mexican food.  I got the super veggie burrito with tofu which was just ok.  A couple of downsides:

1.  I asked for a bowl but was given a burrito instead.
2.  I asked for spicy salsa inside, which was mild at best.
3.  The red salsa at the "salsa bar" had a weird honey taste which I didn't care for.
4.  I paid for the super variety but hardly got any guac and sour cream in my burrito.

The upsides:
1.  Good green salsa - yummy in fact.
2.  Chips were fresher than Taco Bell's.

In this case, there were too many downsides and hence the (2.5) star review. Like I said, I probably won't be back.

excerpts: My husband ordered a Chimichanga.
We waited for about 15 minutes and no food.
Everyone else who ordered after us (and spoke Spanish to the workers) got their food.
Then a lady comes up to us, after we waited over 15 minutes and tells us they cannot make a Chimichanga and that we need to order something else.
WTF?
If you know you cannot make a chimichanga when we order, then say so.
Don't tell us to change our order after we've already waited for so long.
Oh and of course during that whole time we were waiting?
He was charged the chimichanga price.
chimichanga.author: Terry D.
chimichanga.review:
I've been to Iron Cactus many times, when I lived in SOMA, when I visit the ballpark or just in the area.  I like tofu in my burrito and they are the only place I know of with a sauteed tofu option.

The food is less than decent. Edible.  I wouldn't say it's nasty or gross but it's not great or anything.

1 star because the service is just horrible.  Every time I go to Iron Cactus I order the same thing: baby veggie burrito with tofu and guacamole.  Every single time they charge me $1 extra for guacamole and they never put guacamole in it.  I seriously have to watch them like a hawk when they make my burrito and scream over the glass wall to make sure they put guac in.  I'm tired of paying extra and not getting what I ordered. 

Once when I told them there was no quacamole in my burrito, not only did they not make me a new one, they just plopped some guac in a to-go cup.  What the heck am I suppose to do with that? DIp my burrito in guac?

This past visit last week will be our last Iron Cactus visit.  My husband ordered a Chimichanga.  We waited for about 15 minutes and no food.  Everyone else who ordered after us (and spoke Spanish to the workers) got their food.  Then a lady comes up to us, after we waited over 15 minutes and tells us they cannot make a Chimichanga and that we need to order something else.  WTF? If you know you cannot make a chimichanga when we order, then say so.  Don't tell us to change our order after we've already waited for so long.  Oh and of course during that whole time we were waiting? No one was making my tofu burrito.  So total wait time? almost 1/2 an hour! They didn't even reduce the price of my husband's replacement burrito.  He was charged the chimichanga price.

WTH. This place is no bueno!

excerpts: First of all, it is like the pricey version of Chipotle - they have a rice/beans/proteins/veggies/sauces bar that is out for hours... but $15 for a chimichanga that was subpar?
No thank you.
The ambiance is cool for watching sports - take note - they have wooden benches, but the prices they charge are ludicrous for mediocre Mexican.
chimichanga.author: Tammy H.
chimichanga.review:
Wow. Maybe I have just had a bad week of eating out, but coming to the Iron Cactus for lunch really resonated with me in a poor fashion. I work in SOMA so coming here was moreso a decision of convenience than of desire to try their food. 

First of all, it is like the pricey version of Chipotle - they have a rice/beans/proteins/veggies/sauces bar that is out for hours... but $15 for a chimichanga that was subpar? No thank you. The ambiance is cool for watching sports - take note - they have wooden benches, but the prices they charge are ludicrous for mediocre Mexican. I am a SoCal native, so I have been raised on authentic Mexican food my whole life - and not only does this lack authenticity, it lacks flavor, period.

Funny thing is, their food comes out fast (probably because it's been sitting behind the counter waiting for the hungry lunch crowd), but LUKEWARM! Their service is really lackluster, and to add insult to injury, they have a TIP JAR - bad service + feeling entitled to tips??? Sorry Charlie.

I would much rather go to the Mission, order a delicious, reasonably priced burrito and give them a tip. Not only would I receive paramount service, but I'm sure the food would actually taste good. 

I may go back one more time since I work in the area, and am keen on second chances, but definitely not a place I would recommend. It is a poor reflection of what the city of San Francisco has to offer in regards to culinary experiences. Come her if you have low expectations, and really need to eat beans that taste like they came out of a refried beans can.

excerpts: I got the enchilada plate and
every time it's actually better.
What has me addicted is the 5 dollar glass of sangria.
It's good and my glass is big.
Loves!!!
enchilada plate.author: Sophie P.
enchilada plate.review:
Now this is one location where I don't understand the low stars. This is my second time here and my service was OK (not good for so wine to say ok) but my food was slammin. 

I got the enchilada plate and every time it's actually better. What has me addicted is the 5 dollar glass of sangria. It's good and my glass is big. Loves!!!

excerpts: i also ordered up a enchilada plate...which by the way they RAN OUT OF...how the heck do you run out of enchiladas?
enchiladas is just meat and cheese wrapped in a tortillas and topped with enchilada sauce...
a taqueria running out of enchiladas is the same as mcdonalds running out of double cheeseburgers...
i mean...just throw 2 cheeseburgers together and you have yourself a double cheeseburger
enchilada plate.author: Kyu L.
enchilada plate.review:
came here the other day for some grub and i left pretty disappointed...

first of all...granted, i know that this place is located in SOMA, and thus everything is a bit overpriced BUT that doesnt mean the burrito should be 10 bucks...thats just borderline evil.  

oh, and there is nothing "super" about their "super burrito"...its tiny...but still bursting with rice and beans...very little meat...very sad, sad burrito...one of the worst if you ask me...

i also ordered up a enchilada plate...which by the way they RAN OUT OF...how the heck do you run out of enchiladas? enchiladas is just meat and cheese wrapped in a tortillas and topped with enchilada sauce...a taqueria running out of enchiladas is the same as mcdonalds running out of double cheeseburgers...i mean...just throw 2 cheeseburgers together and you have yourself a double cheeseburger right? 

being that you have to pay before they start making stuff, they informed me 15 minutes AFTER i had paid...they wouldnt give me my money back but instead they told me to order anything else, even if it was more expensive....i asked for the garlic prawns as that was the most expensive thing on the menu...then proceeded to eat 2 of them as they tasted old...

on a side note...their corn tortillas are good.

never coming back to eat food here ever again. rather walk 4 miles in the rain to the mission and eat off a street cart....

excerpts: I switch back and forth between the burrito bowl and the enchilada plate - you can't go wrong either way!
enchilada plate.author: Sarah R.
enchilada plate.review:
We love the Iron Cactus. 

My husband, 2 y.o. son and I come in about once a week - my son would live off of their rice and black beans if we allowed him to! We're always greeted with a smile. 

Food is great - everything is perfectly seasoned and hits the spot when you're craving Mexican food. I switch back and forth between the burrito bowl and the enchilada plate - you can't go wrong either way!

We recently had our son's birthday party on their patio and it couldn't have been more perfect. We took suggestions on the food and layout from Ivor, the owner, and he hit it out of the ball park going above and beyond our expectations. There was plenty of yummy food, the weather was perfect, and the space was ideal for little kids - the back door to the patio was closed, so the kids had a safe, contained play space. The adults had plenty of sangria and beer, and no one left hungry! Sal, our host/server, worked hard to ensure we had everything we needed. It was a fantastic day.

Do consider the Iron Cactus for your next party or get-together. It really is a gem right here in SOMA!

excerpts: My friend had the spicy chicken Enchilada plate (10.50) which was tasty, but again, a bit bland.
The sauce had a good flavor with an ever so slight hint of tomato, cumin and chili powder, but it wasn't very exciting to the taste buds.

The portions were adequate, which is what they should be, as I personally feel that these places serve way too much food anyway, and since I'm not looking for value for money, I'm much more interested in quality.
enchilada plate.author: Candace W.
enchilada plate.review:
Here's the deal:

Mexican food as we Americans know isn't true Mexican---it's strictly watered down for the Gringos.  True Mexican food is very complex, yet at the same time very simple and clear.

That said, it's good to see Iron Cactus in the neighborhood, because it is just one more place to eat around the SOMA/Ballpark area, and it's another takeout option, which are scarce.  The area has Fine Dining locked down, but on the rare occasions that I'm not cooking, takeout comes up short for me.

The space is warm and inviting, large, slightly cavernous, lot's of rustic wood furnishing, high, wooded beam ceilings, polished concrete floors, complete with scattered tables and a long communal table in the center.  Dimly lit, with flowers scattered here and there, which as a florist, I'm happy to see,  a large chalk board is scratched with the standard menu as well as the specials.

As this was the first day open, and I arrived 30 minutes before closing, I'd say it was relatively bug-free for the first day,  the service was fast and very friendly.  

However, the food does need a bit of work; I ordered the Crispy tacos ($3.50) which comes with your choice of meat, beans,rice, sour cream and salsa.  I chose the spicy chicken which was tender and pleasantly pulled and stringy, but was very bland for a spicy selection.  I expected the shells to be rustic, handmade corn shells, and whole thing deep-fried (similar to what they do at Dona Tomas's Tacubaya in Berkeley) but the shell I presume was pre-purchased and perhaps flash-fried, but it wasn't objectionable; thin and crisp, with a satisfying crunch, but can get soggy quickly from the whole beans (black) and the salsas and cream.  As I don't drink soda, and only drink beer unless I plan on getting laid, a nice fruity Zinfandel from Santa Cruz, from a vineyard I knew I wasn't going to remember complimented the tacos nicely.

My friend had the spicy chicken Enchilada plate (10.50) which was tasty, but again, a bit bland.  The sauce had a good flavor with an ever so slight hint of tomato, cumin and chili powder, but it wasn't very exciting to the taste buds.  The portions were adequate, which is what they should be, as I personally feel that these places serve way too much food anyway, and since I'm not looking for value for money, I'm much more interested in quality.  The burritos from what I could see resembled overstuffed dish towels, basically the usual-size burrito that you see everywhere, that most people snarf down in one sitting but would take me a week to eat.

All and all I'd say Iron Cactus satisfies the need and perhaps if they concentrate on the food, and maybe branch out and be adventurous, then they'll get better and will probably do a great business during baseball season. 

 But I don't understand why any of these Mexican places don't cook with any exciting spices; whenever I cook Mexican food, I'm using cumin seed, garlic, cayenne pepper, ancho, pasilla and poblano peppers and chiles, achiote and chile powder.  Tacqueria-style food here in the Bay Area is so bland and lifeless and tastes the same everywhere (Azteca Tacqueria is one exception).  All of the meats usually are overcooked and the chicken is boiled instead of roasted, the shrimp is rubbery , whole beans are cooked just in water and salt and the rice is always looks flavorful, but isn't.  And the Pico de Gallo which is mistaken for 'salsa' is always made with those pink insipid, cheap, fast food quality tomatoes (as was the pdg at Iron Cactus).  Although I'm adamantly against using tomatoes past their proper seasons, perhaps these places should consider using Roma tomatoes for their Pico de Gallo, if only just for the color.  A bit more expensive, but hell, this is the Bay Area!

I'd like to see some real Mexican grandmothers open up a place, and show us what real Mexican cuisine is like, or better yet, where the hell is Rick Bayless when you need him?

excerpts: I ordered a Crispy Taco plate with pollo asado (grilled chicken).
Rice, choice of beans and a green salad come with the tacos.
crispy taco plate.author: Wilhelm Y.
crispy taco plate.review:
Considering how much I loathe Victor's around the block I was excited when I realized The Iron Cactus (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZIe-mxk6KWq_ht1jcQ_pAg?select=H9qhiOiC--8oQOFUzTEO8g) had opened up for business.  My excitement was short-lived though.

I had lunch here on Friday morning.  I managed to get in just before the crunch of the lunch time masses.  You order at the counter and you're given a number.  You pay and you wait for your number to be called.  I had been watching how some of the items were being prepared and I noticed the regular burrito was only slightly larger than a baby burrito.  I ordered a Crispy Taco plate with pollo asado (grilled chicken).  Rice, choice of beans and a green salad come with the tacos.  As is my norm I chose the whole black beans although it was interesting to see that they offer refried black beans in addition to the regular refried beans.

The person that takes your order is the person that prepares your food.  The wait for my food was fairly short.  For take out orders I notice they use biodegradable utensils.  You can also use metal utensils if you're eating in.  The interior is very nice with lots of wood tones.

My taco plate (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZIe-mxk6KWq_ht1jcQ_pAg?select=uW_66S5sI52FAQpT5UtmHA) looked pretty good.  My food preparer put lots of chicken meat into the crispy taco shells, but she forgot to give me cheese.  Sour cream, guacamole and pico de gallo (salsa) come on the plate along with the rice, salad and beans.  The chicken was all big chunks of warm, tender, moist chicken breast.  The orange colored seasoning on the chicken was not well defined though and the chicken just tasted bland.  I added parts of my salad, which is served plain with a small lemon wedge, into the taco shell along with the sour cream, the guac and the salsa.

I like chunky guacamole and the avocado here is whipped up too smoothly.  It kind of just ran off of the taco shell instead of staying put.  The Spanish rice mixed with peas and corn was just slightly warm too.  The place is still new so I kind of expect some of the shortfalls.  I'll definitely come back again.  For now they're still better than Victor's but very average.

excerpts: crispy taco plate
, how hard can it be?
better yet, how much reflux can it cause?
the chicken chile verde was so greasy that i had a huge reaction to it even though i'd taken medication in anticipation of a greasy lunch.
i literally had to leave the restaurant and walk off the acid upwelling in my esophagus.
it was horrible.
not only that
crispy taco plate.author: Tera K.
crispy taco plate.review: oh boy. i'd read horrible reviews about this place and it did not disappoint. we went as a big work group for lunch. we preordered and my dish was the only one that didn't show up. she had to ask what i ordered and go check on it. i got my food about 5 min after everyone else. crispy taco plate, how hard can it be? better yet, how much reflux can it cause? the chicken chile verde was so greasy that i had a huge reaction to it even though i'd taken medication in anticipation of a greasy lunch. i literally had to leave the restaurant and walk off the acid upwelling in my esophagus. it was horrible. not only that but the chips had no flavor, the salsa was lame and the guacamole was the most unappealing color i've seen in a long time. would never go back. didn't want to go in the first place.

excerpts: Got the fish taco plate
and I thought it was overpriced ($12) for meh tasting Mexican food.
I won't be coming back unless I get a super Mexican food craving and no one else in the area is open.
fish taco plate.author: Diana F.
fish taco plate.review: Quantity, not quality. The food is only okay but they give you a lot. Got the fish taco plate and I thought it was overpriced ($12) for meh tasting Mexican food. I won't be coming back unless I get a super Mexican food craving and no one else in the area is open.

excerpts: 1 fish taco plate comes with 2 naked fish tacos and beans and rice on the side.
The other fish taco plate comes with 2 fish tacos with guacamole & sour cream on top, and no beans and rice on the side.
Nice man comes and puts carnitas on top of bowl and comes out with another fish taco plate.
fish taco plate.author: l c.
fish taco plate.review:
If good intentions could make food get prepared correctly and taste good, I'd be a happy Iron Cactus customer.  Alas, that's just not the way the world works.  

As others have mentioned, they opened fairly recently, so I'm willing to give it another shot in a few months.  Here are the issues we encountered though:

1) The guy taking the order didn't seem to know the menu. I said, 1 veggie taco plate has 2 tacos right? He said, okay 2 veggie tacos. I said, no just 1 veggie taco plate. He said, okay 1 veggie taco. I said, no I want the plate, with 2 tacos. He did not say anything and wrote down veggie taco plate with a 2 next to it.  Hmm, okay, we'll figure that out later.  

2) The guy who takes the order writes it down in English, but the woman filling the order doesn't know English. He then translates it to Spanish for her. Sorry, but that kinda ruins the assembly-line concept. 

3) At the register, I clarify the taco situation. There's a guacamole situation too, but this is getting long-winded.  We go outside and wait for food.

4) The food takes awhile. 1 fish taco plate comes with 2 naked fish tacos and beans and rice on the side. The other fish taco plate comes with 2 fish tacos with guacamole & sour cream on top, and no beans and rice on the side. Burrito bowl comes with no carnitas on top as ordered.

5) Nice man comes and puts carnitas on top of bowl and comes out with another fish taco plate. This time it has sour cream & beans & rice.  

So, in summary, what you order may not be what you get, and it probably won't taste very good, but it will be served with a smile!

excerpts: I came here with 5 others and got their garlic prawns plate
and it was pretty all right.
The prawns were grilled with mushrooms and came with rice, beans, and a salad, all for about $12.
garlic prawns plate.author: Emy B.
garlic prawns plate.review: Okay, it's been a couple of months since I've been in this place, but totally forgot to do my review.  Maybe because it wasn't too memorable, don't know.  I came here with 5 others and got their garlic prawns plate and it was pretty all right.  The prawns were grilled with mushrooms and came with rice, beans, and a salad, all for about $12.  If hungry, definitely load up on the chips & salsa.  Nothing to write home about really, but would come here again...if someone else came with me.

excerpts: I brought my 2 friends from work to The IC last week, and we had the garlic prawns plate and the Chiplote Prawns which were great.....
garlic prawns plate.author: Victor T.
garlic prawns plate.review: I brought my 2 friends from work to The IC last week, and we had the garlic prawns plate and the Chiplote Prawns which were great.....

excerpts:
I'm about to break it down:

Red salsa is greasy, green salsa needs avocado and more spice.
salsa.author: Gabriela W.
salsa.review:
If you care about your health, fear ecoli, and hepatitis B, don't risk your health by dining at Iron Cactus.

I'll start off with the obvious. This isn't a legit taqueria. This ain't no Mission burrito. This is a sorry excuse for Mexican, and a serious threat to your health.

I'm about to break it down:

Red salsa is greasy, green salsa needs avocado and more spice. Slow down, I'm 100% Mexican, which gives me license to drop these truth bombs. I'll continue. Employees have an attitude. They look annoyed, as if you're doing them a favor by eating there. There's a blonde gentleman that usually takes the orders, and he's guaranteed to mix things up. Have them repeat your order. Twice. If he's not there, that place isn't run professionally. Case and point, my visit with my toddler, on 5/31/18. We drop in about 1:30p. I order for both my daughter and myself. The gentleman that brings our food has a glove on only one hand, which I immediately find strange,  as he's carrying another dish in his un-gloved hand. He drops our entrees off, then proceeds to bus all of the dirty tables, followed by him entering the food preparation area and picking up more entrees for guests. Still with the same dirty glove on. He drops them off at their respective tables. With the same dirty-ass glove on. I mention this to the lady at the cash register, who appears to also be filling the manager role. I tell her it's not a safe practice and he needs to remove his one glove and wash his hands after bussing dirty tables, before picking up guests' food. She agrees to talk to him. She does, then he removes his dirty glove and happily prepares his own lunch at the food preparation area-without washing his hands prior to doing so. If I needed a sign that none of my message had landed with the manager, it came quickly. She takes a new client's order, rings him up, heads straight to the food preparation area without washing her hands, grabs a tortilla and throws it on the grill, patting the tortilla several times, heads to the dining area to bus tables (as ALL of the employees are taking their lunch (this never happens when the gentleman I mention above is acting as the manager), buses tables, heads jack to the food preparation area without washing her hands after handling two tables-worth of dirty dishes, and continues to grab the tortilla off the grill with her bare hands and hands the dude his hepatitis A burrito. WT-----! Seriously, no concept of cleanliness, sanitation, germ and disease transmission! 

They wear a glove in one hand to give the impression that they understand cleanliness and disease transmission prevention. The above clearly paints a very different picture. I. Rest. My. Case. And for the record, I'm a nurse. I know a little something about disease transmission/prevention.

excerpts: I ordered a veggie burrito with mild salsa and a green melon juice.
The juice and the chips that came along with it were quite tasty; however, I found the burrito to be somewhat bland.
Perhaps it would be better with spicy salsa?
It was quite filling though.
I think I would only come back if it was my last option...
salsa.author: Carol M.
salsa.review: I decided to stop by here before catching the Caltrain as it was close by and seemed lively. The service was good but I was a bit disappointed with the food. I ordered a veggie burrito with mild salsa and a green melon juice. The juice and the chips that came along with it were quite tasty; however, I found the burrito to be somewhat bland. Perhaps it would be better with spicy salsa? It was quite filling though. I think I would only come back if it was my last option...

excerpts: But put enough salsa
and hey... it's Monday's lunch ok?
salsa.author: Dante J.
salsa.review: This place is alright and a good value portion wise. Definitely not the most authentic. Kind of similar to Chevy's actually. Well, better than that! But not extraordinarily so. But put enough salsa and hey... it's Monday's lunch ok?

excerpts: Tofu is dope, salsa is on point.
Good place for a vegetarian bite.
5 stars for how good the salsa was alone.
salsa.author: Jeasica C.
salsa.review: Tofu is dope, salsa is on point. Good place for a vegetarian bite. 5 stars for how good the salsa was alone.

excerpts:
-Efficient service
-Heavy pours of wine/beer 
-Clean place
-Free chips and salsa

if you order an entree 
-Close to AT&T Park and Caltrain stop
salsa.author: Megan B.
salsa.review:
I am pretty much vegetarian and dislike tofu so I cannot speak to the meat/tofu burritos, tacos, etc. However, I LOVE their cheese quesadilla with beans and rice and a small side of sour cream. I know it's pretty much comfort, but it's so yummy! 

Other pros:
-Helpful and nice staff
-Efficient service
-Heavy pours of wine/beer 
-Clean place
-Free chips and salsa if you order an entree 
-Close to AT&T Park and Caltrain stop

excerpts: Just chips, no salsa or anything.
salsa.author: Camille C.
salsa.review:
Apparently in SF, places close between lunch & dinner -_-
So we settled for this place.
This place is huge inside, decked out in Giants & Warriors swag!
Reminded me of a turu-turu, the food is in front of you VIA cafeteria style. 

The employees were too busy talking to each other even after they looked at us they kept their little conversation going before finally asking us if we were ready.
BTW; we did look ready since WE WERE STARVING!

I ordered the Cheese Quesadilla, simple.
When we got to the cashier, we paid & were given a small basket of chips. Just chips, no salsa or anything.

We got the Coke in a bottle to drink :)
They gave us a number to put on the table.

Our food came out quick. My quesadilla was surprisingly bigger than I expected :) I asked for Guac on the side (not bad) It was good, how can you really go wrong with it? Just sayin'

They had TV's on playing ESPN so that is always a PLUS!

I saw people leave their dishes on their table & leave, then I also saw people put their dishes in the bus carts, we opted for that. 

Their bathrooms are only on stalls, FYI.

All in all, it was okay.

excerpts: No salsa bar and the chips are extra, and few.
salsa.author: Gonzalo S.
salsa.review: Very plain Mexican food, not horrible, but probably only a place you frequent if you're nearby or in a pinch. Menu is pretty large and they had an interesting chorizo egg torta special, so maybe they have some hidden gems if you taste enough things. No salsa bar and the chips are extra, and few.

excerpts: Chips and salsa also don't come with the meal, you can buy it separately for $5 and they look like they came right off the grocery store shelf...
Just pop off the lid.
There was silverware, but drinks come in a solo cup or tin can.
Sorry...
salsa.author: Kim G.
salsa.review:
When I looked through the window and the place was empty, I was hopeful it was just a fluke. I was sadly mistaken. The atmosphere was cool, the staff was nice enough... Things not to order... Steak Fajitas, Steak burrito (too dry) Wet steak burrito... Chicken tortilla soup. All pretty flavorless. Chips and salsa also don't come with the meal, you can buy it separately for $5 and they look like they came right off the grocery store shelf...
Just pop off the lid. There was silverware, but drinks come in a solo cup or tin can. Sorry...

excerpts: We also got their chips and salsa, which was decent, but nothing special.
Their guac was a bit watered down as well.
Maybe their other food would be better.
I would say, come here to catch a game and order drinks, as they have beer on tap.
Skip their food.
salsa.author: Nancy Z.
salsa.review:
High ceilings, large, open space with multiple flat screens to catch your favorite game.
They have a quite wide variety in their menu and drinks on tap. 
While I appreciate their portion size (my fish tacos plate came with side of guac, sour cream, black beans with cheese and 3 fish tacos), I rather they focus on the food quality. My fish taco was pretty unappetizing...tasted like frozen fish, and I even found a big bone inside...unacceptable. 
We also got their chips and salsa, which was decent, but nothing special. Their guac was a bit watered down as well. 
Maybe their other food would be better. I would say, come here to catch a game and order drinks, as they have beer on tap. Skip their food.

excerpts: I ordered 2 crispy tacos with chicken, a cheese quesadilla (which is one tortilla, not 2) and a small chips and salsa.
It came out to over $26 dollars I was shocked.
I canceled the chips and salsa and came out to $24.
When I got my receipt I was charged for a large salsa for $3.
I questioned why that was on my bill since I canceled any salsa I ordered and she rolled her eyes and gave me my $3 back.
When I got home, I opened the box to find my tacos were not crispy as I ordered, but soft.
Next time I have a Mexican Food craving, I'm going to Victors which is way better a block away.
Don't waste your money.
salsa.author: Micky C.
salsa.review: I'm pretty disappointed. I just got myself lunch from this place and brought $25 cash thinking that would be more than enough for lunch for 1 person. I ordered 2 crispy tacos with chicken, a cheese quesadilla (which is one tortilla, not 2) and a small chips and salsa. It came out to over $26 dollars I was shocked. I canceled the chips and salsa and came out to $24. When I got my receipt I was charged for a large salsa for $3. I questioned why that was on my bill since I canceled any salsa I ordered and she rolled her eyes and gave me my $3 back. When I got home, I opened the box to find my tacos were not crispy as I ordered, but soft. Next time I have a Mexican Food craving, I'm going to Victors which is way better a block away. Don't waste your money.

excerpts: Their salsa game is weak
salsa.author: Oskar D.
salsa.review: Really nice ladies that work there. The food is mediocre and bland. No flavor! I don't know why the Al Pastor meat is so sweat and gross. Taste sort of like tinga, which some of you never had before lol. Chorizo was too salty and tasted weird.. Only thing decent here is the nachos and crispy chicken tacos. Their salsa game is weak

excerpts: The next amazing thing was the total lack of utensils, napkins, and salsa.
I mean we actually had to get up from the table and go prospecting around the place looking for stuff.
salsa.author: Bret F.
salsa.review:
My lunch at the Iron Cactus was a truly unique dining experience.

We had 6 people at our table. The first remarkable thing was that the kitchen managed to get every single order wrong. Fortunately, it doesn't take long to make this sort of food so they got it straightened out after everything got sent back.

The next amazing thing was the total lack of utensils, napkins, and salsa. I mean we actually had to get up from the table and go prospecting around the place looking for stuff. The waiter apparently is used to this and smiled benignly as we ran around gathering up what we needed for eating.

The final straw, for me at least, was that they tried to kill me. Literally. Cleverly hidden in my soft-shell taco was a 2 inch piece of steel wire. Words cannot describe how grateful I am to my mother for teaching me not to wolf my food as a kid. Anyway, having narrowly escaped death, I was content to sip my horchata and watch the rest of my companions tempt fate.

Forewarned is forearmed, of course, and now my friends were picking through their food with great care. One of them found a metal shard in his enchilada - not as deadly as a piece of wire but worth a broken tooth or a trip to the ER.

I would give this place a miss unless you are keen on risking serious bodily injury for really sub-par Mexican food.

excerpts: I also tried their $5.95 Baby Burritos, nicely palm-size and packed full of carnitas, rice, beans, salsa and sour cream.
The $4.95 Cheese Quesadillas were definitely on the greasy side, but gooey cheese is hard to resist in any shape, and the $3.50 Soft Asada Taco was tasty but messy to pick up.
The interior is very communal and loft-like befitting its deep SoMa locale.
All in all, I'd say it's a place to grab a quick bite and hang a bit with friends.
salsa.author: Ed U.
salsa.review:
I'm a bit surprised how much the Iron Cactus has gotten slammed since its opening just a month ago. Either the place made one very bad first impression with those anxious for its opening, or perhaps some of the more vociferous customers may have sat on an actual iron cactus and still feel the searing pain of the needles stuck in their.... Judging from my experience, I have a feeling it's somewhere in between, but I say give it time to get better since the owner seems to be trying hard to become a casual place for locals and Caltrans commuters looking for California-accented Mexican food and beer on tap. 

I was there with Jamie W. for a local community get-together, so I may not have had the most unbiased experience since we were fortunate enough to get a small sampling of several dishes. I admit I didn't feel anything was a complete standout, but a few were on their way to pretty darn good. The $5.25 Ceviche Tostada was a nice treat with shrimp piled high with cilantro on big tortilla chips. The one drawback was that they were a bit too lemony to be completely satisfying.

I also tried their $5.95 Baby Burritos, nicely palm-size and packed full of carnitas, rice, beans, salsa and sour cream. The $4.95 Cheese Quesadillas were definitely on the greasy side, but gooey cheese is hard to resist in any shape, and the $3.50 Soft Asada Taco was tasty but messy to pick up. The interior is very communal and loft-like befitting its deep SoMa locale. All in all, I'd say it's a place to grab a quick bite and hang a bit with friends. If your friends aren't picky eaters, I think you're set. 

FOOD - 3 stars...reasonably good Mexican by way of SoCal 
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...warm vibe for those willing to stick around 
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...I really thought they were pretty nice 
TOTAL - 3 stars...the daggers are out for this place, but trust me, you can do far worse than sitting on an iron cactus

excerpts: de gallo (salsa) come on the plate along with the rice, salad and beans.
The chicken was all big chunks of warm, tender, moist chicken breast.
The orange colored seasoning on the chicken was not well defined though and the chicken just tasted bland.
I added parts of my salad, which is served plain with a small lemon wedge, into the taco shell along with the sour cream, the guac and the salsa.
salsa.author: Wilhelm Y.
salsa.review:
Considering how much I loathe Victor's around the block I was excited when I realized The Iron Cactus (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZIe-mxk6KWq_ht1jcQ_pAg?select=H9qhiOiC--8oQOFUzTEO8g) had opened up for business.  My excitement was short-lived though.

I had lunch here on Friday morning.  I managed to get in just before the crunch of the lunch time masses.  You order at the counter and you're given a number.  You pay and you wait for your number to be called.  I had been watching how some of the items were being prepared and I noticed the regular burrito was only slightly larger than a baby burrito.  I ordered a Crispy Taco plate with pollo asado (grilled chicken).  Rice, choice of beans and a green salad come with the tacos.  As is my norm I chose the whole black beans although it was interesting to see that they offer refried black beans in addition to the regular refried beans.

The person that takes your order is the person that prepares your food.  The wait for my food was fairly short.  For take out orders I notice they use biodegradable utensils.  You can also use metal utensils if you're eating in.  The interior is very nice with lots of wood tones.

My taco plate (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ZIe-mxk6KWq_ht1jcQ_pAg?select=uW_66S5sI52FAQpT5UtmHA) looked pretty good.  My food preparer put lots of chicken meat into the crispy taco shells, but she forgot to give me cheese.  Sour cream, guacamole and pico de gallo (salsa) come on the plate along with the rice, salad and beans.  The chicken was all big chunks of warm, tender, moist chicken breast.  The orange colored seasoning on the chicken was not well defined though and the chicken just tasted bland.  I added parts of my salad, which is served plain with a small lemon wedge, into the taco shell along with the sour cream, the guac and the salsa.

I like chunky guacamole and the avocado here is whipped up too smoothly.  It kind of just ran off of the taco shell instead of staying put.  The Spanish rice mixed with peas and corn was just slightly warm too.  The place is still new so I kind of expect some of the shortfalls.  I'll definitely come back again.  For now they're still better than Victor's but very average.

excerpts:
Salsa
Decor:  Rustic.
Communal Tables, Bench-Seating &

Charming Back Patio

Nice & Friendly

salsa.review:

excerpts: There are free chips and salsa, which is always nice.
salsa.author: Favian S.
salsa.review:
Great atmosphere, especially if you are a sports fan.

I have been here several times, and ordered their super burrito, chicken fajitas, and one of their Mexican-style salads. The food is not overwhelmingly good, but it is filling. Their dishes are somewhat bland, especially their meats, which I don't think is properly seasoned or marinated. The Spanish rice is really dry as well.

There are free chips and salsa, which is always nice.

excerpts: Iron Cactus has the best green salsa that I have found in San Francisco thus far.
If you don't know already, I moved up from San Diego, and have been on the lookout for the best sauces in San Francisco.
salsa.author: Jennifer L.
salsa.review:
I would say that this is 3.5 stars!

Iron Cactus has the best green salsa that I have found in San Francisco thus far.  If you don't know already, I moved up from San Diego, and have been on the lookout for the best sauces in San Francisco.  Nothing even compares to San Diego so far.

I got a regular burrito here.  Service was fast, friendly, and there was plenty of room to sit!  It's close to a lot of bus stops + muni stops + the cal train station, so it's a nice place to meet up before a game or after work before you head home.

Food was okay.  Chicken was delicious, but they put too much rice in my burrito.  Burritos were pretty reasonably priced though -- especially for SF!  I wouldn't mind coming back here again.

excerpts: I am in LOVE with the Mexican Chicken Salad using their super fresh and tasty green and red salsa as dressing.
salsa.author: Kelly W.
salsa.review:
I live and work in SOMA and by default I've probably been here hundreds of times over the past 5 years. I'm finally writing a review.

I am in LOVE with the Mexican Chicken Salad using their super fresh and tasty green and red salsa as dressing. When I'm being "naughty" you can't go wrong with a burrito, taco plate, nachos, tamales...I just love taqueria food. 

This is definitely NorCal style, a bit on the healthier side which is why I'm addicted.

They also have an awesome back patio and I love their sangria, both red and white.

excerpts: The Iron Cactus gives you chips with every meal and they have a lil' salsa bar.
salsa.author: K M.
salsa.review:
The line: Out the door (welcome to SoMA) & pretty fast

The food: HUGE quantities, average quality

I've tried the rancho steak salad and the chipotle prawn plate. They were each roughly $12 after tax (perhaps a little bit much for Tex-Mex). The Iron Cactus gives you chips with every meal and they have a lil' salsa bar. The steak salad was really good: the meat was cooked perfectly, the mixed greens were fresh, and their house dressing is tasty. 

The prawn plate came with rice, beans, chips and tortillas and was way too much food for me! I guess that's not really something to complain about these days though. However, there was a lot of greasy, seasoned water at the bottom of my to-go box, which was kind of unpleasant. (They should use slotted serving spoons!)

A-Ok. Not bad. Not special.

excerpts: I do love their very spicy yellow salsa, but not enough to make me return.
salsa.author: Greg J.
salsa.review:
I've been back 5 times since my review. The food is less tasty each visit, and the service slower. They consistently get my order wrong, and it's very simple: no beans/no rice in my burrito. I do love their very spicy yellow salsa, but not enough to make me return.

So just an update to say I no longer eat here, and don't plan on returning, despite still living a stone's throw away. Sad face. :(

excerpts: Was searching for a good place for a beer and good chips and salsa.
Now I wish I had an Iron Stomach.
salsa.author: Cindy A.
salsa.review:
Was searching for a good place for a beer and good chips and salsa.   Now I wish I had an Iron Stomach.   :P

Plus they nickel and dime you for anything extra.  Sour cream, etc..

excerpts: The green salsa is pretty good, the red salsa is really spicy!
The (free) chips are pretty greasy, but have a nice nutty crunch to them.
salsa.author: Sherry L.
salsa.review: Not the most authentic burrito place, but for SOMA, this is works. When I'm feeling a burrito craving, this is the closest to my apartment. I usually get the super burrito. I like that they have spinach wraps here. The green salsa is pretty good, the red salsa is really spicy! The (free) chips are pretty greasy, but have a nice nutty crunch to them.

excerpts:
I also love the homemadeTamales and the 
green salsa is by far the best in the city.
The service is fast and friendly.
You may not even know that one of the ladies serving you ACTUALLY MADE the tamales...
no store bought food here!
When the line looks long during lunch rush, it moves quickly   The outside patio is a secret find.
Looking to cater a party.
Yes they cater the best Mexican food I've ever had at a party.

I easily give the iron cactus 4.5 stars and 
will keep going back for more!
salsa.author: Tiffany G.
salsa.review:
Thank you for the iron cactus.   I go at least twice a week for the tortilla 
soup with a side of grilled chicken.   I also love the homemadeTamales and the 
green salsa is by far the best in the city.  The service is fast and friendly.   You may not even know that one of the ladies serving you ACTUALLY MADE the tamales...no store bought food here!  When the line looks long during lunch rush, it moves quickly   The outside patio is a secret find.   Looking to cater a party.  Yes they cater the best Mexican food I've ever had at a party.   I easily give the iron cactus 4.5 stars and 
will keep going back for more!

excerpts: I had to douse it in salsa to make it taste somewhat decent.
There are just too many amazing Mexican places in the Bay and SF in particular to settle for bland.
So I probably won't be back (unless, of course, I'm stumbling over myself while drunk as aforementioned).
salsa.author: Justin E.
salsa.review:
To be honest, I stopped by because I was trying to get something better than Subway or some Safeway food before my train. Next time, I'll try and find something else... or just get a sandwich.

Very mediocre. It's the kind of place you need to be absolutely, stumbling over yourself drunk to enjoy your food. It feels more like a bar than a taqueria. I got a carnitas burrito--overpriced and dry. I had to douse it in salsa to make it taste somewhat decent. There are just too many amazing Mexican places in the Bay and SF in particular to settle for bland. So I probably won't be back (unless, of course, I'm stumbling over myself while drunk as aforementioned).

excerpts: but the chips had no flavor, the salsa was lame and the guacamole was the most unappealing color i've seen in a long time.
would never go back.
didn't want to go in the first place.
salsa.author: Tera K.
salsa.review: oh boy. i'd read horrible reviews about this place and it did not disappoint. we went as a big work group for lunch. we preordered and my dish was the only one that didn't show up. she had to ask what i ordered and go check on it. i got my food about 5 min after everyone else. crispy taco plate, how hard can it be? better yet, how much reflux can it cause? the chicken chile verde was so greasy that i had a huge reaction to it even though i'd taken medication in anticipation of a greasy lunch. i literally had to leave the restaurant and walk off the acid upwelling in my esophagus. it was horrible. not only that but the chips had no flavor, the salsa was lame and the guacamole was the most unappealing color i've seen in a long time. would never go back. didn't want to go in the first place.

excerpts: I had to pour on the salsa to give it a chance at deliciousness.
I then started to add in crushed tortilla chips for extra texture.
salsa.author: Derek N.
salsa.review: The super burrito was average. I had to pour on the salsa to give it a chance at deliciousness. I then started to add in crushed tortilla chips for extra texture. It's not that their super burrito is horrible, it just tasted...well, average compared to some other places. My hunger was satisfied and I did finish said super burrito. The salsas were good though...three stars, a-ok.

excerpts:
orders come with chips and salsa
-Tofu
salsa.author: Rohini R.
salsa.review:
This place is right outside the Caltrain station, so I've stopped here for a post-commute burrito far more often than I should ever publicly admit. 

It's a pretty no-frills place, but the quality of food is definitely better than a Chipotle. It's also decently priced, the portions are giant, and they serve beer.  What more do you need?

Other perks:
-Most orders come with chips and salsa
-Tofu fillings available for my fellow vegetarians
-TVs inside playing whatever games are on
-Lots of seating
-Friendly staff

Overall, it's a casual and convenient place to stop by for a meal -- solo or with friends -- if you're in the area.

excerpts: the salsa definitely tastes good when you put it in the burrito making it less dry.
salsa.author: Kathy W.
salsa.review:
after a public transportation journey from Palo Alto to San Francisco, a girl gotta eat. i was craving something light but didnt want Subway from the SF Caltrain Station. I walked into the cafe next door and they said their kitchen just closed and suggested that I go to the Iron Cactus.

I quickly walked over there since i had another bus to catch. I ordered the Chicken Baby Burrito and expressed that I needed it done in 5 minutes and didnt want the guy making the order take forever. i kinda wanted a type of cow-meat but they all looked dry or like they have been sitting out there for a while. the pork looked super oily and heart-clogging. the burrito was nicely wrapped and comes with some tortilla chips which are super oily. the salsa definitely tastes good when you put it in the burrito making it less dry. the baby burrito may not be satisfying for the average person.

overall not bad, but nothing extravagant either.

excerpts:
I asked for spicy salsa inside, which was mild at best.
The red salsa at the "salsa bar" had a weird honey taste which I didn't care for.
Good green salsa - yummy in fact.
salsa.author: Nina V.
salsa.review:
Hmm...I don't think this place is atrocious like some Yelpers, but I don't think I'll be back if I'm craving Mexican food.  I got the super veggie burrito with tofu which was just ok.  A couple of downsides:

1.  I asked for a bowl but was given a burrito instead.
2.  I asked for spicy salsa inside, which was mild at best.
3.  The red salsa at the "salsa bar" had a weird honey taste which I didn't care for.
4.  I paid for the super variety but hardly got any guac and sour cream in my burrito.

The upsides:
1.  Good green salsa - yummy in fact.
2.  Chips were fresher than Taco Bell's.

In this case, there were too many downsides and hence the (2.5) star review. Like I said, I probably won't be back.

excerpts: More organized, better ways to serve the salsa
BUT the salsa could use some definite work (although I'm spoilt by the salsa from Pancho Villa) and actually have more depth in the flavor.
I'd recommend watching the portions a bit ... can save money and also make it easier for the patrons to eat.
There's too much on the tacos when I get them
and I can't pick it up and have to break it up to eat it without looking completely uncoordinated.
salsa.author: Dalia M.
salsa.review:
This place is just a block away and other than Victor's it's the only Taqueria type place in the area within walking distance. I've been here a few times since they opened and I've noticed some improvement. More organized, better ways to serve the salsa but they can still improve what they're serving.

This place does satisfy my craving - I enjoy the carne asada tacos but they are a bit overpriced. BUT the salsa could use some definite work (although I'm spoilt by the salsa from Pancho Villa) and actually have more depth in the flavor. I'd recommend watching the portions a bit ... can save money and also make it easier for the patrons to eat. There's too much on the tacos when I get them and I can't pick it up and have to break it up to eat it without looking completely uncoordinated.

excerpts: Decent prices, so-so sangria, but I did enjoy the complementary chips and salsa!
salsa.author: Gwen T.
salsa.review:
I have no experience with the food at this place, but I sampled their sangria during happy hour. Stepped in as I waited for the next CalTrain, and I gotta say the #1 thing this place has going for it is proximity to the station!

Decent prices, so-so sangria, but I did enjoy the complementary chips and salsa!

excerpts: As a first-timer, I asked her how spicy the "spicy" salsa was, since the only choices for my burrito were mild and spicy.
I meant... is this going to blow my head off, or is it just a nice spicy kick?
She responded "spicy.
FYI - I could barely taste the salsa in my burrito, so I think it's safe to say the spicy is maybe a 2/5 on the spicy scale.
FYI - I could barely taste the salsa in my burrito, so I think it's safe to say the spicy is maybe a 2/5 on the spicy scale.
I ordered a super burrito (comes with meat, beans, cheese, guac, and sour cream) with carne asada, black beans, and spicy salsa.
Maybe I just chose a bad combination, but it was very very bland.
I left about half on my plate.
I ordered a super burrito (comes with meat, beans, cheese, guac, and sour cream) with carne asada, black beans, and spicy salsa.
Maybe I just chose a bad combination, but it was very very bland.
I left about half on my plate.
We also got chips and salsa - chips weren't warm -
it looked
My husband thought his burrito was ok, but if I have any say in it
I won't be going back.
salsa.author: Erin B.
salsa.review:
My husband and I chose Iron Cactus purely on the basis that he wanted Mexican and most of the other Mission Bay-area joints were closed on Sunday.  The 2.5 average on Yelp should've warned me.  My order was taken at the counter by an extremely unfriendly woman.  As a first-timer, I asked her how spicy the "spicy" salsa was, since the only choices for my burrito were mild and spicy.  I meant... is this going to blow my head off, or is it just a nice spicy kick?  She responded "spicy."  Thanks, very helpful.

FYI - I could barely taste the salsa in my burrito, so I think it's safe to say the spicy is maybe a 2/5 on the spicy scale.

I ordered a super burrito (comes with meat, beans, cheese, guac, and sour cream) with carne asada, black beans, and spicy salsa.  Maybe I just chose a bad combination, but it was very very bland.  I left about half on my plate.  We also got chips and salsa - chips weren't warm - it looked liked they'd been sitting out forever.

The lady continued to be rude to us as we tried to figure out when/how you pay and get drinks.

My husband thought his burrito was ok, but if I have any say in it I won't be going back.

excerpts: I went for a carne asada taco with spicy salsa and an al pastor taco with mild salsa.
Grand total: $4.65 with tax.
The cashier was very friendly, even making a point to with me happy holidays.
They have all the burrito necessities: rice, beans, meat, sour cream and salsa (another review says you can get lettuce for no extra charge...
I'll definitely hit that up next time).
The salsa here is tasty, but in no way is it spicy.
The mild is a joke, and the 'hot' salsa is what mild salsa would be at a real Mexican place.
I'm really confused as to these people who say they eat spicy food but thought this place was too spicy.
The spiciest thing they have is the green salsa they have on the tables, which is somewhere between mild and hot at a real Mexican place.
salsa.author: Geoff L.
salsa.review:
So I came here looking to spend about 4 bucks for a quick bite to eat, but was disappointed to see that it was going to cost me $3.50 + tax for one lonely taco. I immediately wrote this place off as an overpriced, overambitious Cali-Mexican place that overcharges because of its prime location. HOWEVER, the person taking orders muttered my two favorite words in the English language...Happy Hour.

Happy Hour 3-6 every day: huge tacos for $2, 20oz beer for $3, appetizers for $3. The beer selection is pretty legit: I recall Sam Adams, Stella Artois, Anchor Steam, Fat Tire and Sierra Nevada. I went for a carne asada taco with spicy salsa and an al pastor taco with mild salsa. Grand total: $4.65 with tax. The cashier was very friendly, even making a point to with me happy holidays. He did inform me, however, that chips are not included with my order.

But anyway, they brought out my tacos, and I was blown away. They are HUGE. I'd say the tacos here are between 1/3 and 2/5 the way to being a normal-sized burrito. They have all the burrito necessities: rice, beans, meat, sour cream and salsa (another review says you can get lettuce for no extra charge...I'll definitely hit that up next time). They're hard to eat as tacos because of the sheer amount of rice, beans and meat, so I got a fork and got to work.

The carne asada and al pastor were both very tasty. Sure, the carne asada was not 100% consistent across the board, and when I first tasted it I couldn't taste barely anything, but when I focused and looked for the taste, I found it and I liked it. The al pastor was even better; nice mix of spices, tender, consistent...I really enjoyed eating it.

The salsa here is tasty, but in no way is it spicy. The mild is a joke, and the 'hot' salsa is what mild salsa would be at a real Mexican place. I'm really confused as to these people who say they eat spicy food but thought this place was too spicy. The spiciest thing they have is the green salsa they have on the tables, which is somewhere between mild and hot at a real Mexican place. I don't get it.

Self-serve water is a huge plus. 'Nuff said.

The take-away: the happy hour here is great. Two huge tacos and a 20oz beer for $7? If I'm ever at the office late, this is gonna be one of my go-to places.

excerpts: flauta appetizer - $5 - served with salsa and lettuce - not fresh
salsa.author: Gloria H.
salsa.review:
Good location.  Seating is good with a rustic feel.  Food, however, is a skip.

super carnitas burrito - w/ guacamole, cheese & sour cream - $8.75 - asked for extra spicy, no spice at all - not carnitas but chicken.  they were not even busy, how do they screw that up?

flauta appetizer - $5 - served with salsa and lettuce - not fresh, it was so chewy and with barely any filling even hubby skipped it. 

horchata - best of the evening.

Next.

excerpts: Make sure you ask for an extra side of dressing and add a little salsa to it.
salsa.author: Fish E.
salsa.review:
Stick to the salads

As far as the tacos, I think they buy the tortillas at safeway. That is really all that comes to my mind.

The burritos are nuked before being served and the chicken tends to be dry.  Though if you do give the Cactus a try and absoulutely need a burrito, order the wet burrito, as the sauce adds some flavor.  

The prices are ridiculous considering the food quality. They do use Niman ranch meats which are of a good quality, but unfortunately good ingredients do not always result in good food.

On the brighter side

The salad with chicken or shrimp (or a combination of the two for a slight up-charge) is really good though I wish the house dressing exuded a little more flavor.  Make sure you ask for an extra side of dressing and add a little salsa to it. Overall it is a nice combination of lettuce, hot peppers, onion, and corn possessing nice flavors and textures.

But If you want flavorful Mexican Food go to the el toyonese truck at best buy. 

The Fish=Wisdom. Wisdom=The Fish

excerpts: Guacamole was soupy, the salsa was runny and the $11 salad was worth $5.
salsa.author: Ted T.
salsa.review: Cool ambiance, but that's about it. Guacamole was soupy, the salsa was runny and the $11 salad was worth $5.

excerpts: The tortilla was rough and dry (not chewy and moist), the rice a little hard and clearly sitting out since lunch, and the "spicy" salsa bland and boring.
salsa.author: Steven H.
salsa.review:
BORING. Is it REALLY that hard to make a decent, flavorful burrito? Dropped in after work on my way home, half expecting something decent as the spot always seems to have at leastt a little activity. I mean, I get it. It's near Caltrain and ATT Park and it's clearly trying to siphon off customers from both venues -- definitely not a destination in and of itself. So what the hell, I was hungry and curious.

Smelled pretty good but as I approached the sneeze shield I saw what could only be described as GROSS hunks of dried out meat sitting in warming trays. Relax, I thought. Maybe they will throw it on the grill for a few seconds but nope, right into the burrito. Maybe it's just so good and flavorful I should treat it like chili, also not high in the looks department but damn good. Ordered, paid ($7.82 for a barebones "regular" burrito) and thought about a beer but when the dude rang up a Corona at $4.50 I said "no thanks." 

Walked the half block to my house and ... remember the dried crusty meat? Still in the burrito and completely flat and tasteless. The tortilla was rough and dry (not chewy and moist), the rice a little hard and clearly sitting out since lunch, and the "spicy" salsa bland and boring. Damn this burrito was useless and silly. I am staring at 90 percent of it in my trashcan pissed that I have to go out and get some real food. Won't be coming back ... expect maybe on Tuesday night for $2.00 Coronas and $1.00 tacos. Like "Heroes" when it started fumbling mid second season, I'll give it one more chance ... I really want to find a decent burrito experience by my crib.

Come on Iron Cactus, don't be afraid to throw out food at 8pm that's been sitting out since lunch. Seriously. One more chance!

excerpts: If hungry, definitely load up on the chips & salsa.
Nothing to write home about really, but would come here again...if someone else came with me.
salsa.author: Emy B.
salsa.review: Okay, it's been a couple of months since I've been in this place, but totally forgot to do my review.  Maybe because it wasn't too memorable, don't know.  I came here with 5 others and got their garlic prawns plate and it was pretty all right.  The prawns were grilled with mushrooms and came with rice, beans, and a salad, all for about $12.  If hungry, definitely load up on the chips & salsa.  Nothing to write home about really, but would come here again...if someone else came with me.

excerpts: Salsa bar was minimal, but decent.
salsa.author: Adam G.
salsa.review:
Bottom line:  decent enough food, but one of the worst values I've yet seen in SF.  

Stopped in here for lunch, and was suitably disappointed.  This was one of the more expensive burritos I've seen in the city, yet was one of the smallest and least filling.  The carne asada did not taste grilled at all.  They also take your order and then reappear with a burrito after a while.  I saw they were overwhelming the burritos with rice, so I asked for a little bit of rice instead.  There was none in there at all.  Just let me direct the assembly of my burrito so that it comes out how I want it.

Salsa bar was minimal, but decent.  Chips that came with the burrito were probably the most well done part of the meal.  No need to go back to this one.  If the food had been as bad as the rest of the experience, this would be an easy single-star review.  That it tasted good, even though it was poorly executed, upped it to a second star.

excerpts: A burrito, chips, salsa and guac and a can of coke for $16.60.
Food in hand, I was frustrated and left and thought maybe the guac, chips and salsa, along with my burrito, would be OK.
I got it home and opened the box which had the chips, salsa and guac.
It was cold, like it had come out of a refrigerator.
The guac was some green concoction that I'd buy in a box at Safeway, not what I'd expect from a mexican restaurant.
The chips tasted day-old, and who likes cold chips?
Not me.
Presentation sucked too, as the guacamole and salsa was splattered all over the chips in the box.
salsa.author: Todd M.
salsa.review:
On my way home from golf and thought about having some mexican. I've driven by Iron Cactus several times and it's in my hood, so could get it and take it to go.  Parking on the street, right in front, so let's give it a try.

Big menu board when you enter.  Lots of choices.  I only had 11 minutes of parking so no long decisions.  I ordered the Burrito with steak, and a side of quacamole.  The lady took my order down and handed me a receipt to take to the cashier.

Turns out she didn't give me a side of guacamole.  She gave me a small appetizer portion, which was $6.50.  I asked the lady to take it off, but now she conveniently doesn't speak English and I had a horrible time explaining to her that I wanted a side of guac, which was only $1.50.  After 2 minutes, I relented and paid for this as she didn't know how to take it off the bill!  A burrito, chips, salsa and guac and a can of coke for $16.60.

Food in hand, I was frustrated and left and thought maybe the guac, chips and salsa, along with my burrito, would be OK.  I got it home and opened the box which had the chips, salsa and guac.  It was cold, like it had come out of a refrigerator.  The guac was some green concoction that I'd buy in a box at Safeway, not what I'd expect from a mexican restaurant.  The chips tasted day-old, and who likes cold chips?  Not me.  Presentation sucked too, as the guacamole and salsa was splattered all over the chips in the box.

The burrito.... who has a burrito without cheese?  Stupid me for assuming a burrito will have cheese. It had lots and lots of rice, and a paltry amount of beef.  I ate it, but I'd barely call it food.

In closing, save your money and go to taco bell, because you'll get better mexican food there.  Don't go to Iron Cactus.  The food is horrible!  If I could give negative stars, I would.

excerpts: I have low expectations for mexican food -- give me food, salsa, and napkins.
Low on salsa everywhere too.
salsa.author: Derrick L.
salsa.review:
I have low expectations for mexican food -- give me food, salsa, and napkins. We got 1.5/3.

It was super slow (mid afternoon, weekend), with maybe a 1/2 dozen people in the whole place. It still took what felt like 10 minutes to take our order and pay.

Then, there were no napkins. Clearly, out of napkins for a long time because other customers were taking semi-used ones from other tables. I told them this behind the counter. They didn't believe me. Someone told me to look "under" (or "behind"?) the table. I looked under the table and repeated that there were no napkins. Then, they believed me. Then, someone else told me to sit down. Huh? All I want are some napkins. Our food is clearly not being touched because we would like some napkins before eating. I see some in the kitchen. I just want a few napkins. I don't understand how finding napkins really takes so long that I should sit down to wait for them.

Low on salsa everywhere too.

Meat was fairly old -- but expected that since we came between meals.

Agree with prior that it is expensive -- but they have a trendy name, so why not?

The food tasted fine to us, so that buys them star #2. My 10 month old son was happy with the avocado slices from my torta.

excerpts: I got the regular works with the extra sour cream,salsa and quacamole.
The more rice,the better too.
I even got a bag of chips,but I am not sure
but I don't know if i was charged.
salsa.author: Dani D.
salsa.review:
Well there was on day I was walking in this area and spotted this place across the street..I thought to myself(oh yum Mexican food) sounds good. At first I did a little browsing and the place looked nice on the outside and when I thought it was safe I went on in. 

I looked around and noticed how clean it was,well maybe because it was still early. However, to the left is where you see the food and then the menu of some sort is above. I was not in one of my moods to stand there and glare at everything and ponder even though there was no one behind me. I was on the go and pretty much hungry. I got a burrito and I believe it was super. Eat half at a time,you know(ha). I went with the spicy chicken,and then at first I wanted refried beans..however I went ahead and said "wait" can I change that to whole beans. I got the regular works with the extra sour cream,salsa and quacamole.The more rice,the better too. I even got a bag of chips,but I am not sure but I don't know if i was charged. It could have been $50 cents,but that is alright. 

I watched the lady make my burrito and I must skip back and say that she was quite friendly and professional when she took my order. That's good,right? 

So as I go to the resigter I pay and I thought the price was ok.However I had seen the beer on display and I was very thirsty,but I had water with me so I had to decline the bubbling eye's of the beer that wanted to be taken away from behind the counter. They offer wine too and that is nice also. 

I did find this place comfy,reasonbly priced,plenty of menu options,nice staff,clean and again the few selection of alcohol beverages would make this place a nice stop for a few drinks after work before heading out somewhere else. 

Not bad,but worth a try. 

P.S Sadly I didn't get to enjoy by burrito til way later,so it wasn't that warm anymore. The chips were ok,nothing to roll around in the bed all happy about. Regardless,the buritto tasted fine and I didn't get sick despite how late I ate it.

excerpts: Ditto for the salsa.
salsa.author: Manny R.
salsa.review:
