It is what it is: a yuppie restaurant with a cool space next to the ballpark and CalTrains.  Your gut instinct tells you it's not good and probably overpriced too.  Still, I was hoping The Iron Cactus would be a cool addition to my hood, but it's not.  

Bland would be an understatement to describe the quesadillas and burritos, as there is absolutely no taste.  Ditto for the salsa.  Just because a "Mexican" restaurant is organic and near the ballpark doesn't mean it has to be bad, right?

Burritos and quesadillas are $7 and smaller-than-average, and a Coors Light is even $5 too.  So you're still paying ballpark prices.  

On the positive side, they have a great space, and I can see it being a fun happy hour place.  

The Iron Cactus probably targets the baseball or CalTrain crowd who just want to eat anything before they go.  Hard to see this place still being around for next year's Opening Day.

excerpts: The free chips and salsa verde were exceptional, but my meal did not live up to the verde.
Not to say that you eat with your eyes, but carne asada should not be gray, and al pastor should not be hot pink.
salsa.author: Kevin M.
salsa.review: The location can't be beat if you're going to a ball game. And considering this proximity, the prices are very reasonable. The free chips and salsa verde were exceptional, but my meal did not live up to the verde. Not to say that you eat with your eyes, but carne asada should not be gray, and al pastor should not be hot pink.

excerpts: It looks like the kind of place you could have a great burrito or some tacos and enjoy some chips, salsa and a beer or marg with friends.
The space is huge and decorated well with a great ambiance.
The chips and salsa were alright though.
salsa.author: Ian M.
salsa.review:
This place is a bummer.  
The food is barely edible.
I should have gone to McDonald's for a fast wrap.

It looks like the kind of place you could have a great burrito or some tacos and enjoy some chips, salsa and a beer or marg with friends.  The space is huge and decorated well with a great ambiance.  That is all it has going for it though.  

My chicken quesadilla order was taken and delivered with a smile.    Unfortunately it was made in a microwave.  They don't even try to hide the microwave from us, it's right there behind the counter - I didn't notice 'til I got my awful dinner.  The cheese was molten lava hot, the tortilla soggy and the meat could not have possibly been cooked the same day.  It was like chewing on chicken leather but with less flavor.

The chips and salsa were alright though.

Bottom line is a microwave has no business in a restaurant.  Ever.  EVER.  Food should have been recently prepared if not cooked just for me.  And this place blows.  

+1 star for at least looking like a good restaurant.

excerpts: No salsa bar.
No selection of frescas.
The one salsa they did give out with their chips (that were admittedly, delicious) was mixed like
salsa.author: Nina A.
salsa.review:
Putting the "Meh" in "Mexican."

Dull, dull, dull, dull. Over-hyped.

Beautiful space. Flavorless food. 2 upper middle-class older (retired?) looking white people working the register area... so that immediately made me suspicious that it's just some lazy investors with money and a bunch of underpaid kitchen laborers who look the part, to cash-in on a seemingly easy cuisine, in a stunning space and in a neighborhood packed full of money to spend on lunch.

It's sad- because I don't see how these guys could fail given their proximity to local offices and the hungry wallets looking for cheap/decent eats. It is a great investment. Brilliant business move. Slap in the face to the integrity of San Francisco's commitment to creative and thoughtful (and well executed) cuisine.

No salsa bar. No selection of frescas. The one salsa they did give out with their chips (that were admittedly, delicious) was mixed like an hour beforehand... so the flavors hadn't permeated and it just tasted amateur.

Oh- and their guacamole- TOTALLY cheater/cheapie taqueria guac, with expensive avacados thinned-out by cheaper sour-cream.

Shame on the owners, for taking advantage of such a perceptibly easy cuisine and filling an incredible restaurant space with such horribly un-inspired and bland food. 

I really wanted to pan them in this review- but unfortunately for that interest, the service was incredibly quick given how slammed they were when I went in... everyone was all smiles, and the owners did seem really nice. Hoping they turn it around.

excerpts: , it's 60 cents for cheese, a dollar for guacamole, and 50 cents if you want chips and salsa with your order.
salsa.author: daisy b.
salsa.review:
Bring all of your nickles and dimes because if you want basics like, oh I don't know, CHEESE, on your taco, you'll need them. That's right, it's 60 cents for cheese, a dollar for guacamole, and 50 cents if you want chips and salsa with your order.

But more than that, the food just doesn't match the gorgeous, rustic decor. I appreciate that it is high-quality and am willing to pay more for that ($9.62 for two crispy tacos with cheese), but I am not willing to pay more for utterly flavorless food and bad service. (I ordered one regular chicken taco and one spicy chicken taco; I was completely unable to tell the difference between the two since neither had any taste at all.)

Skip the prickly people and prices at the Iron Cactus and get a sandwich or crepe at The Creamery (right next door and owned by the same people, I'm pretty sure) instead.

excerpts: That was probably the most amusing offense, but rest assured: nothing tasted like anything, the open area where food is assembled/plated was a disaster (wiping knives on filthy aprons, etc), they place their soft tacos on to paper sheets that stick to the tortilla (thus making it impossible to pick up the taco lest you rip the bottom off), and the salsa is...
salsa.author: Laura F.
salsa.review:
Free associating words with my experience here:  Stressful... overpriced... bland... messy... sh*t show!

Also, I don't know who said to themselves, "You know what this area needs?  ANOTHER Mexican joint!  I mean, there's only like, 4 others in a 5-block radius!  We don't need culinary prowess, we've got ATMOSPHERE!  Surely this is what will make people seeking burritos choose us!"

I wish I had thought to take a photo of my bf's "tortilla soup" for failblog... I observed this process and presentation--- are you ready?  Ok:  Literally, they scooped some chicken and... liquid (?) from what I am almost CERTAIN is the container of mild chicken used for burritos and put it in a bowl.  Then, in they placed some avocado chunks, some cojita cheese, and some cold roasted corn into 3 individual plastic cups, and teetered them on the edge of the bowl.  Voila!  Tortilla soup!  That will be $6.50, please.  
*Notice that nowhere did I make mention of anything resembling, oh, i don't know... a tortilla?

That was probably the most amusing offense, but rest assured: nothing tasted like anything, the open area where food is assembled/plated was a disaster (wiping knives on filthy aprons, etc), they place their soft tacos on to paper sheets that stick to the tortilla (thus making it impossible to pick up the taco lest you rip the bottom off), and the salsa is... I don't even know what the hell is in it, let alone what it's supposed to taste like.

Run awaaaaaaaaaay!

excerpts: I asked for spicey salsa, and got the most mild salsa on the planet.
salsa.author: skot l.
salsa.review:
This place has the worst tacos EVER!

I asked for the spicey chicken, and it had no flavor at all.  The chicken was dry and chewy. Yet it was hanging out in a sauce. I asked for refried beans and got pinto beans.  I asked for spicey salsa, and got the most mild salsa on the planet.  The tortilla stuck to the paper on the plate, I'm not sure why there needs to be paper between food and the plate.

I ended up eating the tacos with a fork, as I couldn't pick up the taco, with my hand, and eat is normally.

Unless you are looking to drink beer here the beverage selection is lacking.

excerpts: Two thin tortillas tried to support a mound of chicken, beans, rice, sour cream, salsa, and cilantro, but couldn't quite do it.
I eat spicy food all the time, and I figured I could handle spicy chicken and spicy salsa.
My bravado almost got the best of me.
salsa.author: David Z.
salsa.review:
I'm flummoxed by the many negative reviews, because I thought Iron Cactus was quite good. It caught my eye as I was walking home from work, and I decided to stop in and get a taco.

I ordered a soft taco with corn tortilla, spicy chicken, and black beans. It cost $3.50, but I soon realized why. It was the most delicious and overstuffed taco I've ever had. Two thin tortillas tried to support a mound of chicken, beans, rice, sour cream, salsa, and cilantro, but couldn't quite do it. 

A word of warning: when they say spicy, they mean it. I eat spicy food all the time, and I figured I could handle spicy chicken and spicy salsa.  My bravado almost got the best of me. The chicken itself was a little dry, but the taco as a whole was delicious and flavorful.

Can't wait to return!

excerpts: But, the guac here was satisfactory, along with the mild and hot fresh salsa.
salsa.author: Christine E.
salsa.review:
I'm surprised with the low ratings of this place.  I actually thought it was good.  I've lived in the SOMA area for a little more than a year now and am always in search of a Mexican joint in the area.  I'm very excited that we now have this place to stop by for some Mexican eats.

We came here on a rainy night while the power was out due to the thunderstorms in the Bay Area this week.  We checked it out to see if it was open and although it was dimly lit due to the power outage, we saw a good number of patrons having their dinner and service staff at the counter.  It was so on!  We were encouraged by the fact that they were still open and were able to serve hot food.

I ordered the burrito with carne asada, my boyfriend ordered the burrito with chili verde and we shared a small order of guacamole and tortilla chips!  I really enjoyed my burrito.  It wasn't monstrously huge, but still filling.  I killed it because I was starving from a light lunch!  The guacamole was okay...I think I like Chipotle's guac better.  But, the guac here was satisfactory, along with the mild and hot fresh salsa.

I can't say this is the best Mexican food I've ever had.  But, honestly, it satisfied my hunger and craving for some good Mexican food.  Plus, it's cheap.  It's also a couple blocks from where I live!  They serve beer and wine and have their own home made sangria, which I'd like to try next time.

The place isn't huge, but not bad if you want to stop by for a quick meal.  The vibe is pretty chill and the service staff was really friendly.

We'll be back!!!  'Just noticed they have a happy hour menu, and I definitely want to check it out!

excerpts: I got the spicy chicken burrito with spicy salsa
and it really was not at all spicy.
The chicken was also pretty flavorless and the burritos -- which sell for $6.95 -- don't even include cheese, lettuce or guacamole.
You're essentially paying "super" burrito prices for a really bland, boring burrito.
salsa.author: Angelo S.
salsa.review:
Really tasteless burritos. I got the spicy chicken burrito with spicy salsa and it really was not at all spicy. The chicken was also pretty flavorless and the burritos -- which sell for $6.95 -- don't even include cheese, lettuce or guacamole. You're essentially paying "super" burrito prices for a really bland, boring burrito.

The only reason that it gets 2 stars instead of 1 is the atmosphere and the chips. It was nice to sit there and eat. It's really big and open and once you order you get a number and wait for someone to bring you your food. The chips are also pretty tasty and crispy as far as your average taqueria chips go.

I probably won't go back there unless someone else offers to pay. These guys need to really step it up.

excerpts: Plus, all you can eat chips and salsa and a block away from where I sleep...
im in.
salsa.author: Luigi A.
salsa.review: Great place if you don't live in the mission and more specifically if you DO  live in SOMA. It isn't the est Mexican in town but it is in this area..and it's so inexpensive! I paid 8 dollars for the quesadilla meal- which is hands down the best thing on the menu! . Plus, all you can eat chips and salsa and a block away from where I sleep... im in.

excerpts:
Salsa - Yummers
4)
The owners are very polite and accommodating.
They brought our food to us, brought flatware and napkins (even though we realized later we were supposed to get it ourselves)
I waited at the counter while the cashier pushed chips around and got salsa...
the line was piling up behind me, so i said, "can i pay?
" and he said, "oh, yay...
No margaritas - Was a little disappointed they weren't serving margaritas, but the red wine selection was pretty good.
) Tacos are a little dry - perhaps they should add a "wetter" salsa (salsa verde?) to their selection - and not over steam their rice...
Tacos should not automatically come with sour cream
salsa.author: Lacey H.
salsa.review:
Wow, I'm surprised the overall star rating for this place is so low!  I'm a big fan of this place.  It is true, that there are things that could be changed for the better, but i think that's the case with all new restaurants.  I came here the week after they opened.  Met some girlfriends here for dinner and drinks, and came again for lunch the following day with my company for my boss's birthday.  Instead of doing pros and cons, although the cons should definitely be taken as "constructive" criticism since they can easily be changed.

Pros:
1) Tortilla Soup - absolutely delicious.  Ate for dinner, and lunch the next day.  The chicken in the soup i had for lunch was WAY too big, and slightly dry.  But everything else was yummy.
2) Atmosphere - great space, great location, outdoor seating
3) Salsa - Yummers
4) The owners are very polite and accommodating.  They brought our food to us, brought flatware and napkins (even though we realized later we were supposed to get it ourselves)
5) Good red and white wine selections
6) Great prices - great happy hour speicals

Constructive Criticism:
1) Staff behind the counter needs to be a little more polite.  They must be new to food service, because they don't seem to understand the phrase, "the customer is always right"
2) Staff behind the cash register needs to be a little more assertive and move the line along.  I waited at the counter while the cashier pushed chips around and got salsa... the line was piling up behind me, so i said, "can i pay?" and he said, "oh, yay..."
3) No margaritas - Was a little disappointed they weren't serving margaritas, but the red wine selection was pretty good.  
4) Tacos are a little dry - perhaps they should add a "wetter" salsa (salsa verde?) to their selection - and not over steam their rice...
5) Tacos should not automatically come with sour cream

excerpts: I had 3 types of chicken, 4 types of beans and 3 types of salsa to choose from, so be prepared to make some very important decisions.
salsa.author: Angela D.
salsa.review:
Now that I'm living in San Francisco, I've got lots of foodie exploring to do, both around my new office and my new home. I was craving a burrito so I used my Yelp iPhone app to find a place close to my office. And that's how I arrived at The Iron Cactus.

There is a large menu and it's a quick ordering process, so if you don't know what you want, I would recommend stepping back to review the menu first. Since I was craving a burrito I went for the Super Burrito, which comes with sour cream and guacamole. I had 3 types of chicken, 4 types of beans and 3 types of salsa to choose from, so be prepared to make some very important decisions.

While it was a big, tasty burrito it had two negatives. One, it unwrapped so I couldn't eat it like a burrito, but had to use a fork and knife. Two, it was overpriced. I think $9 is a little too much for some basic ingredients. That said, I may venture back to try some of the combo plates or tacos, but I did pass a few other Mexican spots on my way back to the office that I may try out first.

excerpts: Seven-plus dollars later, I received a steamed tortilla filled mainly with rice, a smathering of pinto beans, a dash of salsa and a sprinkling of meat.
Allegedly, there was also crema in there, but I found no evidence of it.
I tasted, I added salsa and
salsa.author: Kenny S.
salsa.review:
I ordered a typical carne asada burrito for comparison's sake: pinto beans, spicy, everything on/in it.

Seven-plus dollars later, I received a steamed tortilla filled mainly with rice, a smathering of pinto beans, a dash of salsa and a sprinkling of meat. Allegedly, there was also crema in there, but I found no evidence of it. I doubt if I've ever paid so much for a burrito that lacked cheese and guacamole. The flavors were one note, unfortunately that note was salty. I tasted, I added salsa and yet still I just tasted bland, salty flavors. 

Overall a pretty unmemorable first time experience leaving Chavo's as this neighborhoods best burrito (which isn't exactly a compliment).

excerpts:
I was shocked that my chips did not automatically come with salsa. 
So I asked one of the guys at the counter and he gave me a small container of salsa that didn't look very fresh. 
Anyway, I had to drench my burrito in the not so fresh salsa because the burrito was a little dry and low in flavor.
salsa.author: Alex A.
salsa.review:
I ordered a burrito just so that I could compare burritos to burritos, but Iron Cactus really needs to start working harder and pumping more "iron." The atmosphere was nice and the servers there were nice too, but the food was just not up to par. 
I was shocked that my chips did not automatically come with salsa. So I asked one of the guys at the counter and he gave me a small container of salsa that didn't look very fresh. 
Anyway, I had to drench my burrito in the not so fresh salsa because the burrito was a little dry and low in flavor. 
Hopefully Iron C will make more improvements in the near future.

On a positive note, I did get some free gas =P

excerpts:
Could at least mix a chili or something in when cooking

- The chips in the bag are decent, but no salsa thrown in and no visible salsa bar

- A little on the small side, so that the (cold and taste-free) meat doesn't mix with the other ingredients in the burrito.
salsa.author: A K.
salsa.review:
Sigh. To go order. Really wanted to like this place as it's down the street from my apartment but it's just not good.

- The burrito is cold. There's no way around this. The tortilla stays cold and somewhat wet (wrapped in two layers of foil) while eating

- The carnitas has no flavor at all. Could at least mix a chili or something in when cooking

- The chips in the bag are decent, but no salsa thrown in and no visible salsa bar

- A little on the small side, so that the (cold and taste-free) meat doesn't mix with the other ingredients in the burrito. There is a high meat:other things ratio

- Maybe hire someone who's worked at Chipotle or Taco Bell to avoid having conversations like this with your customers: "I'd like cheese and sour cream"  "Cheese is extra"  "OK"  "So you want extra cheese?"  "Uhh, I want cheese on the burrito"  "It's extra"  "Yes, I get that. I want cheese"

Because of the location and the $8.27 you charge for a small burrito with cheese, your restaurant might do well, but don't delude yourself into thinking that you're doing a good job with the food because of it.

excerpts: You need a salsa bar, the salsas are decent, but people want salsa for their chips, the .50 charge is silly.
salsa.author: Rick R.
salsa.review:
Listen everybody, you are too harsh, this is a new place and is working out the kinks.   The quality of the food is great and this place has potential.

Notes for the very nice owners.  (READ CAREFULLY)

1. Your order execution sucks.   You need to place and order and pick it up or walk the assembly line and pay when complete.  you cannot do both.  Do yourselves a favor and take your staff  to poncho villa or even chipotle for an hour.  Watch and learn.

2. You need a salsa bar, the salsas are decent, but people want salsa for their chips, the .50 charge is silly.  

3. The chicken and carnitas are both awesome, but your execution on the tacos needs work.  1 tortilla is soggy by the time i get back to work.  They are cheap, throw 2 in there.  Also consider a different to go container, trying to pluck to taco out of there is impossible in the single size order.

Thats' all for now, love the flavor here, good quality meats, very tasty.  we'll be back in another couple weeks to see how you are doing.

Best of luck, giving you 4 stars to keep business rolling in, the bad reviews almost kept me out and I think you are just having growing pains.

you have potential.

excerpts: Though it is strange to be given a basket of chips with your order but no salsa.
Actually, there is salsa, but it's in bottles and there are no apparent bowls to pour it into.
salsa.author: Stephen R.
salsa.review:
Cool place, but misses the mark in a couple of important areas.

The food is pretty good. Quality stuff made fresh. As Mexican food goes, it's at least an A-. Though it is strange to be given a basket of chips with your order but no salsa. Actually, there is salsa, but it's in bottles and there are no apparent bowls to pour it into.

The other things are the prices being slightly too high for what you get. And also a fairly awful parking situation. But I suppose both are to be expected in this neighborhood.

For me, I guess the challenges outweigh the incentives.

excerpts: I had the two taco crispy plate and the carne asada was very good but lacked nay real flavor as did the salsa that was included in the meal.
With so many great Mexican restaurants in San Francisco, it's a shame that the Iron Cactus didn't deliver as a great place in SOMA
would have been a nice go to.
salsa.author: Blake B.
salsa.review: The inside of Iron Cactus is very cool and has a nice open feel to it.  The food however was just mediocre.  I had the two taco crispy plate and the carne asada was very good but lacked nay real flavor as did the salsa that was included in the meal.  With so many great Mexican restaurants in San Francisco, it's a shame that the Iron Cactus didn't deliver as a great place in SOMA would have been a nice go to.

excerpts: No real hot salsa, just your gringo kind with tomatoes.
No green chile salsa.
Not sure if they had Tapatio on the tables
salsa.author: May M.
salsa.review:
Ordered take out - 1 carne asado taco and 1 fish taco

Carne asada was kind of peppery and not that flavorful.  Very little meat with too much rice and beans.  Meat was also a bit chewy.  Single tortilla fell apart

Fish taco - where's the fish?  really couldnt find but 3 tiny pieces.  Again too much rice and beans and tortilla fell apart

They did give me some chips with the take out which were like the thin chips you get a Chevys...hmm ok.  No real hot salsa, just your gringo kind with tomatoes.  No green chile salsa.  Not sure if they had Tapatio on the tables

excerpts: You can order yours spicy or mild, and they put the salsa on the side.
Since ours was to go, I asked if they had a salsa bar - and they don't.
There are two types of salsa on each table, so I was given a container to fill up the salsa.
As I read in some reviews, beware of the spicyness of the salsa.
I can handle "hot", but the green salsa on the table that I tasted was more like "fire".
So hot, that you almost couldn't enjoy it.
I know, I am a gringo - but I can handle spicy food - but this was way over the top.
I'll go back, but will stay far away from the green over-the-top-spicy-make-me-sweat-a-little-salsa.
salsa.author: Jason I.
salsa.review:
So if I don't have time to go all the way from the Cal Train station to the Mission and want a quick "fix" - I'd come back again.

Two of us each got a burrito to go:  Chicken for one, Carnitas for the other.  Dining companion said the chicken burrito was good.  The carnitas was good, but not outstanding.  Had a couple of really hard, overcooked pieces of meat in mine that I couldn't eat - but the flavor was good.

Each burrito comes with Meat, Rice, Beans, Sour Cream (can't remember if it came with cheese or not).  You can order yours spicy or mild, and they put the salsa on the side.  Since ours was to go, I asked if they had a salsa bar - and they don't.  There are two types of salsa on each table, so I was given a container to fill up the salsa.

As I read in some reviews, beware of the spicyness of the salsa.  I can handle "hot", but the green salsa on the table that I tasted was more like "fire".  So hot, that you almost couldn't enjoy it.  I know, I am a gringo - but I can handle spicy food - but this was way over the top.  The red sauce on the table I brought home was good.

I am also a "chip" guy, and the chips they sent home with us were great.  Lacking in salt, so I just added my own.  Convenient, close to Cal Train, and in an area that doesn't have much in the way of "take it to go" burrito places.  I'll go back, but will stay far away from the green over-the-top-spicy-make-me-sweat-a-little-salsa.

excerpts: If you order your salsa "spicey", expect raw jalapenos diced into the mix.
salsa.author: H H.
salsa.review:
Best advice:

1. Sit outside on the patio
2. If you order your salsa "spicey", expect raw jalapenos diced into the mix. 

As to what is essentially a cafeteria style Mexican food location, this comes with a few perks, including: a few screens to watch games on, generally very little wait, and a nice secluded outdoor patio (maybe a bit small, but nice when it's not busy).  

Atmosphere is fine, food is OK, clientele is mixed; over an OK place, and one of the better options for mid-priced and mid-quality Mexican in the SOMA/South Beach/Mission Bay area.

excerpts: I had kind of low expectations from some of the reviews here and was pleasantly surprised with my chicken quesadilla served with piping rice/beans/salsa...for $7.
Easily enough to fill me up and then some.
Enough to share.
salsa.author: Mike J.
salsa.review:
I live by the Iron Cactus and finally tried it today, was happy I did :)

I had kind of low expectations from some of the reviews here and was pleasantly surprised with my chicken quesadilla served with piping rice/beans/salsa...for $7.   Easily enough to fill me up and then some.  Enough to share.  A nice step up from a chain like chipotle, for example.  

I give the food 3 stars and 1 star for atmosphere, friendly staff and happy hour specials!  If they could improve the food a tad  it could be a 5 star joint!  Until then it might be a spot for a quick lunch instead of happy hour or dinner out.  Hope it gets there!

Nap time :)

excerpts: A bit pricey, but the food is fresh, the salsa is hot, and the flavors are strong.
It's not a grimey mission mexican place, and it's not some uppity joint either.
I feel like it strikes a good balance between clean, nice decor and down-to-earth mexican food.
big portions.
beer.
and two tvs with sports on.
salsa.author: Derek L.
salsa.review: Randomly walked in late at night.  Don't be fooled by the nice decor and high ceilings, the food is legit.  It hasn't been fully "americanized" into something like a chipotle or baja fresh.   A bit pricey, but the food is fresh, the salsa is hot, and the flavors are strong.   It's not a grimey mission mexican place, and it's not some uppity joint either.  I feel like it strikes a good balance between clean, nice decor and down-to-earth mexican food.  big portions.  beer.  and two tvs with sports on.

excerpts:
Pros:
1) fresh crispy chips - best part of the meal
2) spicy salsa
3) tasty refried beans and rice
4) they gave us a basket of chips and salsa even though we didn't order it
5)
salsa.author: Corinne R.
salsa.review:
I was overjoyed with excitement at a new place to eat near my apartment. But, alas, it was not all I hoped it would be. Because the food was edible and I might go back when hungry in the future, it gets 3 stars.

Pros:
1) fresh crispy chips - best part of the meal
2) spicy salsa
3) tasty refried beans and rice
4) they gave us a basket of chips and salsa even though we didn't order it
5) Horchata and the reddish brown drink (don't know the name) were very tasty and not too sweet

Cons:
1) the person who took our order was barely paying attention and kept interrupting to giggle about something that was going on in the back
2) disorganized service. we weren't given a receipt and they didn't put our drink orders on our meal statement so when our food was brought out they didn't even know we'd ordered drinks.
3) Under-seasoned carnitas
4) Bland tofu (I know I was stupid to try - but I hoped the sauce would be good)
5) lettuce in my burrito event though it wasn't listed as a potential ingredient (so I didn't know to request that it be left out)

excerpts: The two kinds of salsa they offered were very boring as well.
salsa.author: Anish S.
salsa.review:
Hung out in the back patio here today reading a book. They basically get the two stars for nice outdoor seating and convenient location. I'd recommend it for relaxing.

To be fully honest, I only had a bite of my buddy's burrito which he claimed was pretty bland. He ordered it spicy - and it had literally no spice. The two kinds of salsa they offered were very boring as well.

You could tell by the clientele that they really aren't succeeding, or trying, to make exciting food. The crowd was all white and older - the kind you'd find talking about how they like Chipotle. (Sorry, I'm not very PC over here)

The prices are way too high for the low quality as well.

For those in the area looking for flavorful Mexican food, go to Chavo's (4th and Bryant) or Maya (2nd and Harrison). Both awesome places.

excerpts: The chicken wasn't very spicy but the salsa sure was.
The chips were light and tasty.
salsa.author: Garrett D.
salsa.review:
We went here for dinner the other night.  Overall I was pretty happy.  This place is a good addition to the neighborhood.  SOMA was in need of a decent taqueria.  

I had the spicy chicken burrito.  I wouldn't put it in my top San Francisco burritos but it was a heck of a lot better than the other burritos I've had around SOMA.  The chicken wasn't very spicy but the salsa sure was.  The chips were light and tasty.  They also have a few beers on tap and good prices on pitchers.

This place has the potential to be great.  I hope the owners read some of the feedback and work on the food a bit.

excerpts: The tacos are generous portions with a great spicy salsa and fresh meat.
You can get your burritos with wheat tortillas and black beans and grilled chicken...love it!
Recently I needed a location to host a charity event and as a good neighbor, the Iron Cactus opened their doors.
We had a fabulous event and appreciate the Iron Cactus supporting a good cause to help clean up our Ocean.
Thank you!
salsa.author: Akva A.
salsa.review:
I live and work near the Iron Cactus and the Creamery. Very glad they came to the neighborhood.  Wonderful food, great warm and inviting staff, nice fun and clean space.  The tacos are generous portions with a great spicy salsa and fresh meat. You can get your burritos with wheat tortillas and black beans and grilled chicken...love it!
Recently I needed a location to host a charity event and as a good neighbor, the Iron Cactus opened their doors.  We had a fabulous event and appreciate the Iron Cactus supporting a good cause to help clean up our Ocean. Thank you!

excerpts: The burritos are very expensive and need tablespoons full of salsa to have taste.
salsa.author: J S.
salsa.review:
Worst Mexican in San Francisco. 

Con:  high prices, rude services, bad tasting food, they send you home with the wrong order


I'm a vegan and my husband ordered me a spinach tortilla burrito with tofu and they sent it home with chicken in it. I didn't find out until I took a bite out of it. 

Another time I asked for a spinach tortilla and they sent me home with flour. 

Another time I asked if they had fresh chips that were warm and they said no and pointed me to the stacks of bagged chips that had been sitting around for hours. They have an area where they warm chips under a light, but it looks as if the staff got lazy and pre-bagged chips which over time got cold and stale. 

The burritos are very expensive and need tablespoons full of salsa to have taste.

excerpts: Well, I didn't get the chips, but I did get a plate with a really good heaping fish taco AND rice AND beans AND the good spicy salsa.
So hm!
They spared me the fat-adding unnecessary chips and gave me a hella complete meal.
salsa.author: Dana D.
salsa.review:
This is a nice space with really nice patio out back.  I was, like a lot of other reviewers, ready to dislike this place because it's owned by gringos. Bleeding heart white liberal right here! ha.

I've eaten here twice and if you doctor your food with the salsas on the table (the green is freakin delicious) it's really good food. Last time I was there I got one fish taco and asked for an order of chips (they're good, man), ready to pay for the chips. Well, I didn't get the chips, but I did get a plate with a really good heaping fish taco AND rice AND beans AND the good spicy salsa. So hm! They spared me the fat-adding unnecessary chips and gave me a hella complete meal. Pretty great for $4.50.  

Every person on the staff is really friendly and they're trying hard, people. The place has been full the 3 times I've gone at lunchtime (once the line was too long and I didn't want to wait) -- the negative reviews don't seem to be impacting the business.

excerpts: My two pieces of constructive feedback that take priority for me were the chicken and the salsa on the tables.
The chicken seemed too oily, almost on the greasy side.
I ordered the regular chicken that comes out of the serving area where they make the burritos.
With this extra amount of oil l
I hope their price doesn't change based on OPEC's oil production.
The green salsa on the table was beyond hot.
It was "darn hot".
So in closing, if those two things change then a star for each.
salsa.author: M E.
salsa.review:
It's about time for a Taqueria in Mission Bay. The venue is quite sizeable and the staff are very friendly. I also ran into the owners and they seem like good guys.
The rice and beans here are great. The prices seem right. 
My two pieces of constructive feedback that take priority for me were the chicken and the salsa on the tables.
The chicken seemed too oily, almost on the greasy side. I ordered the regular chicken that comes out of the serving area where they make the burritos.  With this extra amount of oil l I hope their price doesn't change based on OPEC's oil production. ;)
The green salsa on the table was beyond hot. It was "darn hot". 
So in closing, if those two things change then a star for each.

excerpts: The only thing I really liked about this place is the guacamole and salsa they have out!
Which is almost unheard of-to have all you can eat guacamole.
I dont hate it here
and if I HAD to eat here
again I would not get pork or black beans.. so you can be your own judge.
I gave this place 2 stars and not 1 because the service was really GREAT and the decor was relaxing and clean.
salsa.author: E N.
salsa.review: This place is OK..and I like plain food so I was very surprised at how 'not good' the food was.  I got the taco salad and it was plain and dry.. I thought ok I got a salad at a Mexican food place let me give it another try.  So I ordered a baby-burrito this time of carnitas-yuck! I threw it away after I ate half of it(its not very big) it tasted smoky and carnitas shouldn't taste like pulled pork it should have a rich pork flavor.  The black beans were dry and not that great in taste.  The only thing I really liked about this place is the guacamole and salsa they have out! Which is almost unheard of-to have all you can eat guacamole.  I dont hate it here and if I HAD to eat here again I would not get pork or black beans.. so you can be your own judge.  I gave this place 2 stars and not 1 because the service was really GREAT and the decor was relaxing and clean.

excerpts: (i was sad i couldn't have a marg); 2. table service rather than cafeteria style; and 3. better salsa.
salsa.author: Niki G.
salsa.review:
I'm sad to see so many people give poor reviews to this place.  Maybe it's because they were just opened when most people reviewed them, but it seems that they've taken the critiques on yelp and improved their service...when we ate there, we had great service, friendly staff, and pretty good food.  You can't really beat their happy hour ($2 tacos, half off some appies, and cheap beer & wine), and the space is cool.  They could definitely use: 1. a liquor license (i was sad i couldn't have a marg); 2. table service rather than cafeteria style; and 3. better salsa.   

The food wasn't the best mexican food, but if you go in expecting decent street tacos, burritos and reasonable prices, you'll be happy. I'll definitely go back.

excerpts: So great food, great atmosphere, bad service, chintzy chips and salsa baskets.
salsa.author: Nick V.
salsa.review: Its really a shame that the service is so ridiculously bad, because the food is fantastic and authentic.  We really enjoy heading here before a giants game for a burrito and a couple of beers.  They have a great outdoor patio with a TV too, which provides a great spot to enjoy the weather and a ball game.  So great food, great atmosphere, bad service, chintzy chips and salsa baskets.

excerpts: Free and unlimited chips and salsa is also nice.
salsa.author: Eric W.
salsa.review:
I work near here so we go for lunch ever so often. The food is good - not great and not bad. I think it is on the high end of the price scale for quality, but they get away with it because of the location and the place itself is nice. I like the patio out back for lunch on nice days. Free and unlimited chips and salsa is also nice. 

Yes I will be back but having lived in the Mission for a few years I know there are WAY better Mexican places to be had. But hey, it's convenient and it's not bad.

excerpts: I've never tasted a more watery, bland roasted tomato salsa.
6) Put less rice into your burritos.
It's starchy, bland filler.
See (11) again.
Actually, go directly to (11) right now and memorize it as a mantra.
salsa.author: Mark J.
salsa.review:
Never let white people run a burritoria.  Most of the scathing remarks I wanted to make were made in other reviews, I'm going to give The Iron Cactus some free consulting:

1) Move people through line single file.  See point (2) to understand how that might be possible.
2) Organize your ingredient in the order a burrito is made.  Notice in most restaurants, they put the cheese and the burrito first, and then the fixin's in order.  That way, people can move down the line single file.
3) Eliminate the slips order tickets.  No one needs to write down an order like "burrito on whole wheat with chicken and cheese."  Write the type of burrito on the foil with an indelible pen or stick a colored toothpick into the finished burrito.  Note that (2) facilitates this.
4) Stop bringing burritos to the table.  Not only will you no longer need to employ the cute spiky-blond-haired runner to bring the burrito to my table, but you'll have customers who sit down with food.  Note that (3) is prerequisite for this.
5) Get rid of both of those dreadful salsas you have at the table.  The green one is too hot to have any taste and I've never tasted a more watery, bland roasted tomato salsa. See (11).
6) Put less rice into your burritos.  It's starchy, bland filler.  See (11) again.  Actually, go directly to (11) right now and memorize it as a mantra.
7) When you make a burrito with cheese, put it in a steamer to melt the cheese onto the burrito.  No one likes hard, cold cheese in the middle of their burrito.
8) Chips should not be extra: the cost of throwing a few chips onto someone's plate is minimal. (See (9) for clarification)
9) Source your chips from a quality chip manufacturer.  Yours tasted like a step above Doritos.
10) Take The Card (i.e., American Express).  Don't give me the crap about their fees: it's a cost of doing business.
11) Put some flavor and spice into your food.  None of the food was "bad," but newspaper has more flavor. Cilantro, chilis, peppers, pepper, salt, lime, etc. . . try 'em out.
12) "Super" option, please! 

(bonus) 13) Visit a joint like Mexico au Parc or Victor's with a notebook and copy down exactly what they do.

excerpts: The salsa verde is pretty good.
salsa.author: Klevin D.
salsa.review: I'm still trying to find good Mexican food within walking distance to my work, but this satisfies your craving for a burrito. It's just not the best burrito ever. The salsa verde is pretty good.

excerpts: However, the food does need a bit of work; I ordered the Crispy tacos ($3.50) which comes with your choice of meat, beans,rice, sour cream and salsa.
I chose the spicy chicken which was tender and pleasantly pulled and stringy, but was very bland for a spicy selection.
I expected the shells to be rustic, handmade corn shells, and whole thing deep-fried (similar to what they do at Dona Tomas's Tacubaya in Berkeley)
but the shell I presume was pre-purchased and perhaps flash-fried, but
it wasn't objectionable; thin and crisp, with a satisfying crunch, but can get soggy quickly from the whole beans (black) and the salsas and cream.
As I don't drink soda, and only drink beer unless I plan on getting laid, a nice fruity Zinfandel from Santa Cruz, from a vineyard
And the Pico de Gallo which is mistaken for 'salsa' is always made with those pink insipid, cheap, fast food quality tomatoes (as was the pdg at Iron Cactus).
Although I'm adamantly against using tomatoes past their proper seasons, perhaps these places should consider using Roma tomatoes for their Pico de Gallo, if only just for the color.
salsa.author: Candace W.
salsa.review:
Here's the deal:

Mexican food as we Americans know isn't true Mexican---it's strictly watered down for the Gringos.  True Mexican food is very complex, yet at the same time very simple and clear.

That said, it's good to see Iron Cactus in the neighborhood, because it is just one more place to eat around the SOMA/Ballpark area, and it's another takeout option, which are scarce.  The area has Fine Dining locked down, but on the rare occasions that I'm not cooking, takeout comes up short for me.

The space is warm and inviting, large, slightly cavernous, lot's of rustic wood furnishing, high, wooded beam ceilings, polished concrete floors, complete with scattered tables and a long communal table in the center.  Dimly lit, with flowers scattered here and there, which as a florist, I'm happy to see,  a large chalk board is scratched with the standard menu as well as the specials.

As this was the first day open, and I arrived 30 minutes before closing, I'd say it was relatively bug-free for the first day,  the service was fast and very friendly.  

However, the food does need a bit of work; I ordered the Crispy tacos ($3.50) which comes with your choice of meat, beans,rice, sour cream and salsa.  I chose the spicy chicken which was tender and pleasantly pulled and stringy, but was very bland for a spicy selection.  I expected the shells to be rustic, handmade corn shells, and whole thing deep-fried (similar to what they do at Dona Tomas's Tacubaya in Berkeley) but the shell I presume was pre-purchased and perhaps flash-fried, but it wasn't objectionable; thin and crisp, with a satisfying crunch, but can get soggy quickly from the whole beans (black) and the salsas and cream.  As I don't drink soda, and only drink beer unless I plan on getting laid, a nice fruity Zinfandel from Santa Cruz, from a vineyard I knew I wasn't going to remember complimented the tacos nicely.

My friend had the spicy chicken Enchilada plate (10.50) which was tasty, but again, a bit bland.  The sauce had a good flavor with an ever so slight hint of tomato, cumin and chili powder, but it wasn't very exciting to the taste buds.  The portions were adequate, which is what they should be, as I personally feel that these places serve way too much food anyway, and since I'm not looking for value for money, I'm much more interested in quality.  The burritos from what I could see resembled overstuffed dish towels, basically the usual-size burrito that you see everywhere, that most people snarf down in one sitting but would take me a week to eat.

All and all I'd say Iron Cactus satisfies the need and perhaps if they concentrate on the food, and maybe branch out and be adventurous, then they'll get better and will probably do a great business during baseball season. 

 But I don't understand why any of these Mexican places don't cook with any exciting spices; whenever I cook Mexican food, I'm using cumin seed, garlic, cayenne pepper, ancho, pasilla and poblano peppers and chiles, achiote and chile powder.  Tacqueria-style food here in the Bay Area is so bland and lifeless and tastes the same everywhere (Azteca Tacqueria is one exception).  All of the meats usually are overcooked and the chicken is boiled instead of roasted, the shrimp is rubbery , whole beans are cooked just in water and salt and the rice is always looks flavorful, but isn't.  And the Pico de Gallo which is mistaken for 'salsa' is always made with those pink insipid, cheap, fast food quality tomatoes (as was the pdg at Iron Cactus).  Although I'm adamantly against using tomatoes past their proper seasons, perhaps these places should consider using Roma tomatoes for their Pico de Gallo, if only just for the color.  A bit more expensive, but hell, this is the Bay Area!

I'd like to see some real Mexican grandmothers open up a place, and show us what real Mexican cuisine is like, or better yet, where the hell is Rick Bayless when you need him?

excerpts:
a couple of things really kept it from being a much stronger spot:

- no salsa bar.
salsa.author: Tom H.
salsa.review:
really, a 3.5 star review, but i'll bump it up to counter the haters. 
first day, not bad. the carnitas tacos i had were heaping and pretty tasty. the other dishes they had out for display, such as the camarones, looked pretty good as well. a couple of things really kept it from being a much stronger spot:

- no salsa bar. i know you are trying to be fancy, but some of us need our pico de gallo, man. 

- tacos had only one torilla, and it was steamed, making it gummy and sticky (i even had trouble getting it off the waxed paper). either grill that thing, or up it to two torillas.

- an option for "super" on the tacos would have been awesome, as i really could have gone for some guac. 

anyway, like i said, first day. this place has a lot of potential,and hopefully they can rise to it.

excerpts: I got the spicy chicken with black beans, and there was also rice and salsa inside.
The lady taking my order asked if I wanted it spicy so
of course I said yes.
Perk: free basket of chips and two kinds of salsa!!
By the time I finished my burrito and chips/salsa my mouth was feeling the heat ...just how I like it.
By baby burrito with chips and salsa was $5.95 (ok $6-something including tax)
salsa.author: Caitlin B.
salsa.review:
I went here for lunch today and am am now baffled that I came back to my computer and Yelp and saw an avg of 2.5 stars?? Definitely not. 4 stars. solid.

For what it is I thought it was great!  mexican food, order at the counter, get a number, they bring it to your table. I thought they also had a nice lot of seating, with some outside too. It's not in the mission so maybe it's a few dollars more than some other burrito spots, but whatever, this was more convenient.

I had the baby burrito and my boyfriend had the regular burrito. The baby one was noticably smaller, but was it enough food? Of course! I got the spicy chicken with black beans, and there was also rice and salsa inside. The lady taking my order asked if I wanted it spicy so of course I said yes. Perk: free basket of chips and two kinds of salsa!! I definitely liked the spicy red one better than the green one. 

By the time I finished my burrito and chips/salsa my mouth was feeling the heat ...just how I like it. 

I probably wouldn't recommend going out of your way to come here, but if you are going to be in the area and are looking for an under $10 meal, well then I would definitely recommend it. By baby burrito with chips and salsa was $5.95 (ok $6-something including tax)

excerpts: Additionally, no napkins and salsa were provided, they didn't even ask.
Torta was bland.
This place is on the SHIT LIST for good.
salsa.author: Nelson F.
salsa.review: Unbelievable.....BAD, SLOW, EXPENSIVE.  Ordered a torta with the al pastor meat (bbq pork) to go which was over $9. I watched and waited 20 minutes while they made burritos for people who were behind me in line.  Finally, I sat down to eat the torta at my office and to my surprise, there was barely any meat; should have been piled on like a burrito.  The meat was spread thin like peanut butter.  Additionally, no napkins and salsa were provided, they didn't even ask.   Torta was bland.  This place is on the SHIT LIST for good.

excerpts: The quesadillas were soggy and bland despite the cashier asking us if we wanted "crispy tortillas" and "spicy salsa".
salsa.author: Joshua W.
salsa.review: The  Iron Cactus has a great location and look unfortunately the food is really lacking. If you don't like cold spots in your burrito this is the place for you, because my whole burrito was piping cold. Both friends also had plates of lukewarm food that took too long on serving time and short on flavor. The quesadillas were soggy and bland despite the cashier asking us if we wanted "crispy tortillas" and "spicy salsa".  One thing the place has going for it in the food department is that the carne asada on my burrito was tender. But unfortunately it was not warm. Did we hit an off night? Maybe. Am I willing to go back to Mission Bay to give it a second shot. No.

excerpts: The green sauce they have table side is up there with Cumbre on 16th and Valencia and Cancuns hots green salsa.
The people who work here push this place over to a 5 star review from 4.
Such friendly and nice people.
I always enjoy going here not only for the food and atmosphere but for the great people who work at this restaurant
make it a truly great experience.
I will be there tomorrow again for delicious tacos and 2 dollar coronas to support the best Mexican restaurant in SOMA.
salsa.author: Harry E.
salsa.review: I really think these reviews are off base.  Yes maybe the burrito might be better in the mission at a few places but I only get Tacos here primarily and they are delicious.  The Carnitas and Chicken are especially good and the Carne isnt bad also.  But on Tuesday the mini tacos are the best.  1 dollar tacos and 2 dollar coronas are great.  The green sauce they have table side is up there with Cumbre on 16th and Valencia and Cancuns hots green salsa.  The people who work here push this place over to a 5 star review from 4.  Such friendly and nice people.  I always enjoy going here not only for the food and atmosphere but for the great people who work at this restaurant make it a truly great experience.  I will be there tomorrow again for delicious tacos and 2 dollar coronas to support the best Mexican restaurant in SOMA.

excerpts:

-house made tortilla chips make any nachos better
-Convenient location right across from the 4th Caltrain, which makes it easy if I need to wait a while for the next train.
salsa.author: Jefferson C.
salsa.review:
this place goes down to 2 stars,
they cut the hours of the happy hour, and it only covers tacos + beer
no more nachos BOOO!

----------------------------------------------
I'm not rating this based on taqueria quality in relation to other taq's in SF, but solely based on the amazing happy hour deals which I had previously ignored until today.

M-F 3-6pm half price apps or $2 tacos, which makes a regular order of nachos just over 2 bucks (this is a standard size square box filled up too).

Pros:

-refried black beans (only seen at papalote and the revamp pancho villa)

-house made tortilla chips make any nachos better
-Convenient location right across from the 4th Caltrain, which makes it easy if I need to wait a while for the next train.

Negs:
regular price I probably wouldn't repeat - although I may choose this over Victor's in the area, but not mexico au parc in south park - burritowise

salsa.review:
Don't even know what to say about this place. As people below state, trust your gut instinct. I'm mexican and know what REAL mexican food is, bottom line it doesn't reallllly exist in SF (minus late night tacos de adobada o carnitas). In noo way did I walk expecting this to even compete with Chavos or other "staples" of the SOMA & ballpark corridor. BUT this won't even compete with Chevys, yes ...that bad. Being a so cal kid, sometimes I admit I crave a cheesy syrup based margarita and nasty chips n salsa = el torito, but THIS place makes el torito seem like an awesome eatery in Jalisco. ajjjuaaa

Bottom line it was horrible... even the salsa sucked and as I was paying I said "ok I'll pay for chips if they aren't included" cashier said "oh noo they will be in ur bag". Got back to my office.. didn't even care about the flautas, but searched and searched and no chips. 

I wanted to get chipfaced and didn't get the chance to. 

Sooo ni modo iron cactus... suerte para la proxima. Can we do minus -1 star?

excerpts: None of the dishes were memorable and the ingredients, while allegedly fresh, were rather bland and had to rely on the salsa for flavor.
If the Iron Cactus gets competent staff and jazzes up their dishes (or at least obtains a full liquor license so they can serve margaritas) then they have all the makings of a success.
Until then I'll keep getting my neighborhood Mexican fix at Tres Agaves.
salsa.author: Max G.
salsa.review:
Having seen the Cactus being built as it's just down the street from me I was excited to check it out last Friday after a long day at work.
First off - this isn't really a restaurant, it's more of a fast food joint. You order your grub at the counter, pay for it and take a number. Nothing wrong with that (almost all the best Mexican food I've had was from street vendors), just don't come here expecting white table cloths and a mariachi band.
Unfortunately the level of service is belied even by the humble interior (I guess they're going for the faux vintage look that's inexplicably still popular in SOMA). It took 5 minutes to explain my complicated order of 2 soft tacos, 2 crispy tacos and a 'dilla to the cashier. After that she inexplicably decided to tack on a burrito to my order. The manager was pleasant, however, and quickly refunded me the burrito bucks.
The food took significantly longer than I expected to arrive, and when it did it was savory but not spectacular. None of the dishes were memorable and the ingredients, while allegedly fresh, were rather bland and had to rely on the salsa for flavor.
If the Iron Cactus gets competent staff and jazzes up their dishes (or at least obtains a full liquor license so they can serve margaritas) then they have all the makings of a success. Until then I'll keep getting my neighborhood Mexican fix at Tres Agaves.

excerpts: The spicy salsa was totally flavorless.
salsa.author: peter j.
salsa.review: Edible, but bland and overpriced. The spicy salsa was totally flavorless. And $7 for a veg burrito that doesn't even have avocado? Come on.

excerpts: And the salsa used might as well be genetically modified cardboard.
Blah!
Also tried some fish tacos once
and they were equally null and void of flavor.
I think I'll pass on this place in the future.
salsa.author: j d.
salsa.review: OK, I don't think there's any reason a review and rating for a restaurant can't be based on trying just one or two items.  With that said...I find it hard to believe that they can't get even a simple bean and rice burrito to taste decent.  I have on two occasions asked them to make this spicy and both times now it's about as bland and unspicy as I think is possible to make it.  And the salsa used might as well be genetically modified cardboard.  Blah!  Also tried some fish tacos once and they were equally null and void of flavor.  I think I'll pass on this place in the future.

excerpts: What I didnt like was the little salsa containers on the tables.
I just do not think that is sanitary having little social salsa pots all over the place.
This is a city full of all kinds of people and I dont know what the last 10 people did with that container and spoon.
ugh....
I wish I could have gotten my salsa from a salsa bar or on the side.

Wrong....
Public salsa jars - yuck
Needs a personality.

:
Offer a "super" or "wet" burrito including all the options - guac, sour cream, cheese, salsa etc.
s

Salsa bar... or salsa on the side
Ask your patrons what they think - smile and welcome them...
salsa.author: Kev S.
salsa.review:
We went there on Tuesday night aroudn 8PM.
It was not too busy so we walked right up to the counter.
We both love burritos so I ordered the beef and my partner ordered the chicken.   
Like many of the reviews we were amazed that we had to pay extra for CHEESE???   (I am from Wisconsin where normally cheese is included on everything for free :-)

I should have looked at my receipt because I saw someone mention that they charge 50cents for chips?   I just assumed they came with it and they were on my plate.  I will have to check on that.  Its not very clear.

The other odd thing was there was a guy there that I think was the owner or manager.  He walked around in and out of the kitchen.  He looked exhausted and very unhappy.   I am sure starting a restaurant is a nightmare but if it was me I would have put on a happy face and said hello to people and welcomed them and asked them how things were.   He basically ignored the existence of all the customers never once talking to anyone but the staff???


The space is great.  The people were friendly to us but the food was my big concern reading the reviews.  Luckily both of us really liked our burritos and they were pretty good size.  I have to say the steak had some really good seasoning.   What I didnt like was the little salsa containers on the tables.  I just do not think that is sanitary having little social salsa pots all over the place.   This is a city full of all kinds of people and I dont know what the last 10 people did with that container and spoon.  ugh.... I wish I could have gotten my salsa from a salsa bar or on the side.

So to sum it up:

Pros:
Food was good
Burrito was good size
Atmosphere is cool but mellow


Cons:
Cheese is extra?  Wrong....
Public salsa jars - yuck
Needs a personality.  Staff was nice but distant - manager had head in sand.

Recommendations to owners:
Offer a "super" or "wet" burrito including all the options - guac, sour cream, cheese, salsa etc. s
Salsa bar... or salsa on the side
Ask your patrons what they think - smile and welcome them...

Chow!

excerpts: They thought about the little things, like keeping the home-made salsa on ice, some big flat screens up in the corners for enertainment, high open ceilings..its just a good feel.
salsa.author: John B.
salsa.review: This place is exaclty what it should be, for where it is. Busy during the lunch hours, and good amount of traffic, so the food is always fresh. Some healthy options like burrito bowl, etc.. They thought about the little things, like keeping the home-made salsa on ice, some big flat screens up in the corners for enertainment, high open ceilings..its just a good feel.

excerpts: i had to dump salsa all over it to give it any sort of taste!
I was with my friend walking back to her place
and I mentioned to her that I was hungry.
She suggested The Iron Cactus because it was across the street
but she warned me that the food is not the best.
I thought I'd give it a try...
The ordering, paying, and getting my food seemed and was so complicated... and they were SO DAMN SLOW!!
Other taquerias that I go into the city have great systems getting those burritos down the assembly line.
There is no assembly line here what-so-ever!
salsa.author: Jasen L.
salsa.review: This is the worst place for mexican food ever!!!  The baby burrito I ordered was soo bland... i had to dump salsa all over it to give it any sort of taste!  I was with my friend walking back to her place and I mentioned to her that I was hungry.  She suggested The Iron Cactus because it was across the street but she warned me that the food is not the best.  I thought I'd give it a try... The ordering, paying, and getting my food seemed and was so complicated... and they were SO DAMN SLOW!!  Other taquerias that I go into the city have great systems getting those burritos down the assembly line.  There is no assembly line here what-so-ever!  The place was very slow with not that many patrons.. and the wait for my baby burrito... nearly 20 minutes!!! its like my burrito disappeared for awhile... never ever again will I go to this establishment!  I wonder if the owner ever tried mexican food.. this place needs serious over-haul!

excerpts: Fajitas with black beans, great salsa verde, & a happy hour beer?
What better way to head out to the ballpark?
Fourth, actually outdoor seating areas that have sunlight!!!
Fifth, gracious owners.
On more than one occasion I have had the pleasure to meet both.
They remember my name, the lil ones, my favorite items, & take a true interest in getting to know their patrons & what we might be needing to improve our experience.
Now to all you yuppie comment making people...why not be a little more judgmental in your life?
Labels are for clothing & food products, not people.
To label this place as a yuppie hangout could not be furthest from the truth.
I have seen families, business folks, nannies, mommies, students & HARD WORKING people who much like the most of us are hoping to get the best value for our dollars.
To each their own, but for me, I am thrilled to have found the Iron Cactus & the Creamery, too!
Now, just be sure to save me a seat.....
salsa.author: N J.
salsa.review:
My new find.....
First, let's say that the place is immaculate, not to mention so forward in using reclaimed & recycled  materials in their decor/structure. Bravo!!!
Second, the staff is fantastic. They are friendly & super helpful in a genuine authentic way. They are not just patronizing for business sake. This also includes the guys & gals who work in the Creamery next door. I frequently venture over with lil ones just exploring & finding their way in the world, but never have received that "oh, no, here comes the kiddies-quick hide the..." sigh & eyeroll that is way to commonplace in this world. Now, I understand some children aren't as well behaved, but to assume that they will be a nightmare to deal with is just plain unfair. The staff here are always smiling & waving back & treat all there guests as just that. 
Third, DELICIOUS! FRESH! QUALITY! cuisine. YOu know how rare that is? Peppers that taste like peppers, not the oil or grease or lard some people use to stretch dollar. Fajitas with black beans, great salsa verde, & a happy hour beer? What better way to head out to the ballpark? 
Fourth, actually outdoor seating areas that have sunlight!!! 
Fifth, gracious owners. On more than one occasion I have had the pleasure to meet both. They remember my name, the lil ones, my favorite items, & take a true interest in getting to know their patrons & what we might be needing to improve our experience. 
Now to all you yuppie comment making people...why not be a little more judgmental in your life? Labels are for clothing & food products, not people. To label this place as a yuppie hangout could not be furthest from the truth. I have seen families, business folks, nannies, mommies, students & HARD WORKING people who much like the most of us are hoping to get the best value for our dollars. 
To each their own, but for me, I am thrilled to have found the Iron Cactus & the Creamery, too!
Now, just be sure to save me a seat.....

excerpts: That's $5.90 for a "baby burrito" (rice, beans, salsa; cheese is extra).
Third Street Grill made this mistake when it first opened, too, but it has since added a veggie burrito option with lower pricing.

Also, service at The Iron Cactus is super slow and inefficient -- maybe they should take some tips from Mexico Au Parc (which I am also not too keen on but which I do not loathe) to see how to cycle people through?
salsa.author: Midori S.
salsa.review: I, too, loathe Victor's and Chavo's and was super excited to see The Iron Cactus open shop. The space is cool, and the burritos are actually better than the aforementioned places'. However, The Iron Cactus is super uncool to charge the same amount for burritos with without meat as for burritos with meat. That's $5.90 for a "baby burrito" (rice, beans, salsa; cheese is extra). Third Street Grill made this mistake when it first opened, too, but it has since added a veggie burrito option with lower pricing. Also, service at The Iron Cactus is super slow and inefficient -- maybe they should take some tips from Mexico Au Parc (which I am also not too keen on but which I do not loathe) to see how to cycle people through?

excerpts: The spicy option is hardly noticeable and the salsa is watery.
On the plus side, the people are friendly and they offer beer and wine.
In a pinch, I would head to panera instead.
If you have more time, I would go to Tres Agaves.
salsa.author: MIcah S.
salsa.review: I have been here three times since they opened. Every time it gets worse and worse. Two of the three times, they mixed up my order. In general, the food is over salted and under seasoned. The nachos have very little cheese. The meat in the burritos and the soup are too salty and lack flavor. The spicy option is hardly noticeable and the salsa is watery. On the plus side, the people are friendly and they offer beer and wine. In a pinch, I would head to panera instead. If you have more time, I would go to Tres Agaves.

omg

The mexican people who work there are not happy to have a job.
They are smiling thru their angry teeth, is it that bad to work there???

if it does not change, the rice, the salsa, 
and whatnot i will be peessed.
btw, they didn't even put salsa in my burrito.
i had to ask for chips and salsa, omg!
salsa.author: Sophia M.
salsa.review:
Ok, I will give it a chance.
But before I go back, I want the cooks to go to Chipotle and learn how to cook rice.
The rice is miserable.  Esp since that is 90 % of the burrito they stuff in there.
The steak is msg ridden with no beef flavor.
The salsa? omg, it is sooo bland.  
The mexican people who work there are not happy to have a job.  They are smiling thru their angry teeth, is it that bad to work there???
I agree, I want to have a good burrito place around here but this is just ridiculous, i would rather have a taco bell than this piece of trash.  The place is also wayy too cold.  maybe i'll go for a beer but food? i don't think so.  this place has the personality of the ridiculous coffee shop next door.  
I can only say that i am glad there aren't too many people who go there since i don't want to run into a crowd of non food knowing people when i take my daily walk.
I can say that i will let my dog do his business around this place tho.
Why so upset? Cuz i love my california burritos and i can't believe  they must have money to burn.
I will visit again in 8 days.  if it does not change, the rice, the salsa, 
and whatnot i will be peessed. btw, they didn't even put salsa in my burrito.  i had to ask for chips and salsa, omg!
